story:
We were utterly intoxicated with one another…

INTRODUCTION

Still Water is an intimate drama that explores the relationship between lovers who are utterly intoxicated with one another but never on the same page. Our female antagonist is in severe denial about their shared alcohol dependancy and constantly pulls her boyfriend down with her so that she will not feel so alone. Our script embraces how self awareness and destruction collide within a painful and vibrant narrative. Each moment explores human connection in the most naked and volatile sense. Our themes are self conflict, intoxication, and dysfunctional love. Our script calls for unconventional albeit recognizable storytelling techniques. Montage narrated by dialogue and design that complements the content through contrast. Our non-linear timeline will allow us to pack immense meaning into a fifteen minute experience. The acting, as always, will be the deciding factor as to how the film will be received and how our story will affect those who are watching.

AESTHETIC

The look of our film takes inspiration from THE TREE OF LIFE as directed by Terrence Malick and HER as directed by Spike Jonze. Picture slightly faded colours with bright and vibrant backgrounds all in widescreen to completely absorb both the objects and environment of our world. There will be a glamorous element to the lighting which will juxtapose the drama of our story. The cinematography will touch on implications of the sublime without falling into them, staying relative to love and trust between humans. This look will be achieved through the use of white, natural lighting and contrasted subjects to maintain depth of environment.

PERFORMANCES

The complexity of our story can only be told through the nuances of both the dialogue and the characters. The performances will be evocative and subtle with a focus on body language over spoken word and symbolism over explicit nature. The name of the game is not what is said but what is left unsaid. Our story addresses contemporary issues of the subconscious and the plague of self that mars every single person. Our script tackles the seeming inability to commit to the best version of oneself. The characters are accessible because they project a side of self that everyone can relate to. Motivation for our actors comes from the inner tension and struggle between the person they want to be, the person they really are and who others see them as.

SOUND DESIGN

The sound design in our film will go as far as possible before crossing into experimental. Because of our non-linear storyline, sound will cue certain places we have been before and will become an adhesive to the overall narrative. The focus will stay on emersion into the location with clear and powerful dialogue. The contemporary score will provide a backbone for the dramatic tone but stay away from distraction or blatant emotional influence. Sound and music will both be minimalist in nature, simply adding depth to the visuals and story.

A NOTE FROM OUR SCREENWRITER

I am fascinated by personal dependency and the inability to differentiate between healthy and unhealthy affection. When people walk away from this film, I hope our story will inspire them to feel things more deeply in the same way that sobriety forces me to experience emotion. I want to encourage our audience to live with those feelings on the surface and embrace their own inner struggle as an unexpected source of empowerment.

- CJ McGillivray

EXPENSES

The intimate nature of our script demands professionalism, precision and outstanding quality. This means having all the resources we need to turn our concept into something tangible. Your financial support will go directly toward the following expenses:

  • PRODUCTION DESIGN: Our visual design requires insight and precision through the selection of vibrant colours and complimentary textures. Balance will help create a noninvasive visual landscape and subtle architecture that will support the drama unfolding on screen
  • COSTUME DESIGN: Our costume design will contribute toward the appearance of each character with subtle but distinct intent. Personalities become entangled with increased emotional dependancy: the emotional mirroring results in our ensemble dressing more and more similar through the progression of time.
  • HAIR AND MAKE UP: Our characters will look occasionally dishevelled throughout the film. The actors will portray a dramatic age range of five years within the context of our fifteen minute film. Hair and make up will assist our actors in portraying a younger or more mature look depending on where they are in the progression of the film.
  • EQUIPMENT RENTALS: Our production crew need the proper resources and equipment in order to create something visually stunning and poignant. That means proper lighting equipment and various camera lenses to capture our story with beautiful precision.
  • CATERING: Our cast and crew are donating their time and efforts in order to make this story happen. We want to show our immense gratitude and appreciation by providing healthy, quality meals that can sustain our team through four long days of filming.
  • TRANSPORTATION: Our various locations make up an integral story element within the context of our film. Effective transportation and planning will keep us effective and efficient when moving from one location to another over the course of our production schedule.
  • DISTRIBUTION: Our story can only resonate with audience members provided we are able to reach them. Our marketing and distribution expenses will include but are not limited to online distribution, film festival submission costs, poster printing and theatre rental costs for our upcoming film premiere.
  • PUBLICITY: Our film needs to garner excitement and support throughout the process so we can engage a broad audience with the full impact of our story. Our publicity expenses will include professional behind the scenes photography, poster design, media connections and online exposure through resources such as The International Movie Database.

CHALLENGES

Our film has a complex narrative that exposes the raw nature of both recovery and dependency. How can we do this without placing judgement? Our film is not a public service announcement. One of our primary challenges was discovering how to explore those intimate themes through compassion and personal insight. Our script openly explores how substance abuse can undoubtedly empower or weaken our ability to connect with one other. The characters represent opposing mental states and shared dependency: emotional dependency, romantic dependency and substance dependency. Our script opposes the traditional black and white narrative, finding nuance and compassion in each moment. Through our efforts we will overcome any challenging preconceived notions and perceptions about both dependency and recovery.

GRATITUDE

Raise a glass to the nights we cannot remember with the friends we will never forget…

How can we truly express our gratitude for your financial and moral support? You are empowering young artists to create something unique and vibrant in efforts to make a lasting impact. To the right you will see that our team has assembled some memorable donation perks as our way of giving thanks. But even if you are unable to make a donation we are grateful for your time and efforts in reviewing our campaign. There are numerous ways to get involved regardless of your financial situation. You also share our campaign to get the word out and encourage others to donate. Please let us know if you have any questions or comments as we are always happy to start a dialogue.

PLEASE NOTE: For the donation perks entitled Turning Water Into Wine and Turning Water Into Champagne, your voucher offers physical delivery of the alcoholic beverage in accordance with campaign regulations.




OUR CAST

Kelly McCabe as COLE OWENS

Maddie Phillips as CHARLOTTE ROSS

Nia Roam as JAMIE OWENS

Georgia Bradner as ALEXA CONNOLLY


OUR CREW

Paul Human, DIRECTOR

CJ McGillivray, SCREENWRITER and PRODUCTION DESIGNER

Allyson Fournier, PRODUCER and CASTING DIRECTOR

Wes Chew, DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY

Michelle Grossmith, COSTUME DESIGNER

One of our primary challenges was discovering how to explore those intimate themes through compassion and personal insight. Our script openly explores how substance abuse can undoubtedly empower or weaken our ability to connect with one other. The characters represent opposing mental states and shared dependency: emotional dependency, romantic dependency and substance dependency. Our script opposes the traditional black and white narrative, finding nuance and compassion in each moment. Through our efforts we will overcome any challenging preconceived notions and perceptions about both dependency and recovery.
GRATITUDE
Raise a glass to the nights we cannot remember with the friends we will never forget…
How can we truly express our gratitude for your financial and moral support? You are empowering young artists to create something unique and vibrant in efforts to make a lasting impact. To the right you will see that our team has assembled some memorable donation perks as our way of giving thanks. But even if you are unable to make a donation we are grateful for your time and efforts in reviewing our campaign. There are numerous ways to get involved regardless of your financial situation. You also share our campaign to get the word out and encourage others to donate. Please let us know if you have any questions or comments as we are always happy to start a dialogue.
PLEASE NOTE: For the donation perks entitled Turning Water Into Wine and Turning Water Into Champagne, your voucher offers physical delivery of the alcoholic beverage in accordance with campaign regulations.






OUR CAST


Kelly McCabe as COLE OWENS



Maddie Phillips as CHARLOTTE ROSS




Nia Roam as JAMIE OWENS



Georgia Bradner as ALEXA CONNOLLY


OUR CREW


Paul Human, DIRECTOR



CJ McGillivray, SCREENWRITER and PRODUCTION DESIGNER



Allyson Fournier, PRODUCER and CASTING DIRECTOR



Wes Chew, DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY




Michelle Grossmith, COSTUME DESIGNER

story:
Legend Has It - Synopsis

'Legend has it that the groundskeeper heard a disturbance in that house one night. When he went inside to check on the family he never came back out. Whoever was in that house that night had killed him too.'

Legend has it’ is a short horror film set in the mid 1970’s. It follows two male protagonists. Kane, an energetic and charismatic thrill seeker who is always looking for his next adventure and Oliver, Kane’s lifetime best friend and aspiring journalist who is the polar opposite of Kane’s personality. In an attempt to help bring Oliver out of his comfort zone, Kane surprises Oliver with an adventure. They arrive at the desolate and foreboding house on Summer Hill road, which legend has it was the site of a number of gruesome and horrific murders. What they don’t know is, some legends are best left alone.

What We Need & What You Get

Just like any other film our film requires a budget that we can use to bring this story to life. We have decided that a budget of $4,000 would be enough to fund our project. Our team has spent many hours deciding where the money will be best spent. 

  • Our unique location 25%
We have spent weeks and weeks finding the perfect location to set this story. The location we have selected is absolutely full of character and awaits our arrival. 
  • Travel & Accommodation  25%
As our filming location is rather isolated we need to transport all of our equipment and crew to location and also provide appropriate accommodation for the team. 
  • Props & on set expenses 25%
Being that our film is set in the 1970's we need to ensure we keep our props, costumes and all other aspects of our film true to the time era. 
  • Post-production 25%
A crucial part of film making is ensuring that the post-production is done with the highest quality and care. This means we need to invest enough money into our colour grading and sound mixing to have the highest possible quality for the finished film. 

Although we do hope and set out to achieve our goal of $4,000, we understand that we might not raise the full budget. If this is the case we will reassess our expenses and adjust the budget accordingly. Regardless of how much money is raised, Legend Has It will be made with the highest possible quality! 


The Team




Gemma Sergeant will be taking on the role of Director for Legend Has It. Gemma has recently finished making a short film that explores the idea of feminism and the meanings behind it. Gemma is most looking forward to directing her first short horror film, as it’s been an interest for a long time. Gemma’s ultimate goal is to deliver a short film that the audience won’t forget.



Jake Collins is the writer and producer of Legend Has It. He has recently completed a short documentary on the topic of change. Jake is most looking forward to bringing the story of Legend Has It to life on the big screen. Jake’s ultimate goal is to inspire other students to write and bring their stories to life.


Scott Gillies will be taking on the role of Cinematographer. Scott has recently finished filming an independent short film exploring the city of Melbourne and its inhabitants.  Scott’s photographic skills mean that Legend Has It will be shot in a way that gives our story a unique and professional look. Scott’s ultimate goal is to win an award for best Cinematographer and expects this upcoming film to be his best work yet.


Hayden Hadley-Powell will be taking on the role of sound designer and will also be working on post-production. Hayden spends much of his time in the edit studios using Avid Media Composer, piecing together short films. Hayden is most looking forward to experimenting with new sounds effects that’ll take our story to the next level. Hayden’s ultimate goal is to produced the best sound possible for films.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can donate but by visiting this page you have already supported our project. It would mean the word to us by taking it one step further by liking and sharing our page on social media.
https://www.facebook.com/legendhasitshortfilm
Thank you for your support!

story:
Video with French subtitles:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fWuDOqHF-nE

Who are we?




We are young Mexican filmmakers who graduated from MiamiDade College with an Associate and Science degree in Film Production. A Mexican writer and a french gallerist and producer. We are the Writers, Producers and Directors of Barbarita Tortilla.

Our mission as filmmakers is to recognize the stories that need to be seen, the stories of the hidden heroes of everyday life, who face real problems, have the strength to fix them, and be the light of hope for those who surround them.


Nosotras omos  jóvenes  cineastas, mexicanas  graduadas del Miami Dade College, con un diplomado en Producción de cine. Una escritora mexicana y una galerista y productora francesa.  Somos las escritoras, productoras y directoras de Barbarita Tortilla. 

Nuestra misión como jóvenes cineastas, es traer a la luz las historias olvidadas de los héroes escondidos. Los héroes de cada día que se enfrentan a problemas reales y que tienen las fuerzas de solucionarlos. Héroes, que dan el ejemplo para su gente y que crean luz, esperanza y lo mas importante, un cambio social. 


Nous sommes deux jeunes cinéastes mexicaines, diplômées de Miami Dade College et de la Science de la production cinématographique, un écrivain mexicain et une galeriste et productrice  française. Nous sommes auteurs, producteurs et directeurs de Barbarita Tortilla.

Notre mission en tant que cinéastes est de réaliser des histoires qui doivent être vues. Des histoires de héros cachés, des héros de la vie quotidienne qui font face à de réels problèmes. Et qui malgré tout ont la force d’aller de l’avant et sont la lumière et l'espoir pour celles et ceux qui les entourent.


Karla and Maria Jose Noriega Pedroza.

www.themexicantwins.com

theluckytwinsproductions@gmail.com

VIMEO: https://vimeo.com/user40206342

Rofaïda Zaïd

http://www.rzg.fr

Stephany Prieto 

www.bajolaslilas.com


¿Who is Barbarita Tortilla?



Barbarita (Last Name) or best known as Barbarita Tortilla is a 40 years

old woman who was born in Poncitlan, Jalisco. She was abused by her 

husband, and once miscarried a baby because he hit her while she was 

pregnant. However, Barbarita had the strength to put an end to the destructive 

relationship. What strike us the most was realizing that Barbarita was not a rare 

case. Even though she was strong enough to have the “pantalones” to 

overcome the situation, there are still millions of women that are going through 

the same circumstance, who are immersed in this degrading reality and need 

the inspiration of Barbarita. 


Barbarita Tortilla, es una mujer de 40 años de edad nacida en Poncitlan, Jalisco. 

Barbarita sufrió todo tipo de abusos por parte de su marido. Incluso en una ocasión

 perdido un bebe a causa de los golpes que su esposo le propinaba.  

Sin embargo, Barbarita tuvo la fuerza de poner un alto a su relación destructiva. 

 Lo que realmente nos impacto, es darnos cuenta de que Barbarita es un caso entre 

millones. 


Barbarita connue comme Barbarita Tortilla est une femme de 40 ans née à Jalisco.  

Alors qu'elle était enceinte, son mari l'a violée et battue, elle a alors perdu le bébé 

qu'elle portait.

Cependant, Barbarita a pris la résolution de mettre fin à cette situation terrible et à 

cette relation destructrice. 

Ce qui nous a le plus frappée a été de réaliser que Barbarita n’est pas un cas rare. 

Elle a eu la chance d'avoir les "cojones" de briser ce tabou, mais il existe des 

millions de femmes qui vivent dans la même situation et NOUS (oui je parle vous 

aussi!) devons leur donner le soutien et les "cojones" dont elles ont besoin

pour mettre fin à ce fléau.


¿Why we choose Barbarita Tortilla? 

You will fall in love with her charming-warrior spirit and her contagious 

smile, because she sets an example and inspires us to be strong and stay true 

to our morals.


Por que nos enamoramos de su carisma y espíritu guerrero. Ella es el perfecto 

ejemplo que las mujeres necesitan para romper sus miedos y salir adelante. 


Vous tomberez sous le charme de son esprit  guerrier et son sourire contagieux, 

parce qu'elle montre l'exemple et nous inspire en restant forte et fidèle à ses 

moeurs.


¿Why those that matter, how can this issue affect you 
directly?

Violence against women is a social issue that occurs around the world 

regardless of economic status, race or age, 3 out of 5 women in Mexico have 

suffered or are suffering from a form of abuse, meaning that you might know 

someone who is going through this.


La violencia hacia las mujeres es un problema que no respeta estatus económico, ni 

nacionalidad. En Mexico, 2 de cada 3 mujeres han sufrido o están sufriendo algún 

tipo de violencia. Esto significa que tu conoces a alguna de estas victimas, solo que 

quizás no lo sabias. Imagina que puede ser tu compañera, tu amiga, tu hermana, tu 

novia o tu mama.


La violence faite aux femmes est un problème social qui touche les femmes du

 monde entier peu importe leur statut économique, l'éthnie ou l'âge. 3 femmes sur

 5 au Mexico en ont souffert ou en souffrent, ce qui veut dire que vous en 

connaissez sûrement une dans votre entourage.


¿How funds will be used?


With your donations, we will cover the expenses of the short film “Barbarita Tortilla” which will help us spread the message of hope for the women of the world. The money raised will cover:

1) Providing food (A full meal, snacks, water), transportation (equipment van, gasoline, etc.

2) Renting equipment (lighting, sound, specialty gear), props, wardrobe, and set design.

3) Cast/crew per diem.

4) Post-production.

5) Festivals

Every cent that you donate will contribute to the goal, which is put an end to this issue. We understand that not everyone can donate, but you can really help us by spreading the word and reposting this link! Even if we do not reach the goal, we will move the entire world if necessary to make this project happen, and make the amazing story of Barbarita Tortilla known! The money raised will go into our film’s bank account and we will continue to work until we reach our goal. From the bottom of our hearts, 

Thank you !

El gran problema es que la mayoria de las victimas creen que merecen ser tratadas de esa manera o creen que es algo normal. La solucion mas eficaz para este problema es la educacion ¿y que mejor manera de enseñar, que a travez del cine? Tenemos que enseñarles a nuestras mujeres que ser golpeadas y maltratadas no es algo que nadie merezca o deba tolerar. 

Necesitamos tu ayuda para cubrir todos los gastos de producción del cortometraje. 

El dinero será utilizado de la siguiente manera:

1. Comida para todo el equipo de producción. (Agua, Snacks, comida entera)

2. Transporte para el equipo de producción. (Gasolina, Equipo Técnico, etc.)

3. Cast/crew per diem.

4. Post-Producción (Edición, Diseño de Sonido, Corrección de color)

5. Festivales 

Cada centavo que se done contribuirá a la causa, que es poner un alto a la violencia contra la mujer. Nosotras entendemos que no todo el mundo esta en la 

posibilidad de donar. Por eso, compartiendo el link de la campaña en diferentes plataformas sociales puede hacer la diferencia. 


Avec vos dons, nous allons couvrir les frais du court-métrage "Barbarita Tortilla" et diffuser le message d'un avenir meilleur pour les femmes du monde entier. L'argent récolté couvrira les frais suivants :

1) Fournir de la nourriture (repas complet, collations, eau...) à l'équipe

2) location de l'équipement (lumière, sons, caméra, accessoires etc)

3) Rémunération de l'équipe 

4) Post production

5) Inscription aux festivals

Chaque centime que vous donnerez contribuera à mettre un terme à ce problème dans le long terme. Nous comprenons que tout le monde ne peut pas contribuer financièrement à ce projet, mais vous pouvez nous aider en diffusant ce lien!

Même si nous ne parvenons pas à atteindre notre but, nous allons remuer ciel et terre pour rendre ce projet possible et faire connaître l'histoire incroyable de Barbarita Tortilla !

Du fond du cœur, nous vous remercions!

story:
Six million daily riders.

Six million stories.

Scenes From The Underground is a feature film that takes place almost entirely on the New York Subway system over the course of a single 24 hour period.  

With true stories compiled from interviews with hundreds of New Yorkers over the course of seven years, Scenes features a diverse cast of over fifty characters, all struggling with the challenges of everyday survival.
Whether they be tales of joy and sorrow, romance and heartbreak, or the mundane and the sublime, the paths of these New Yorkers will forever be changed by the friends and strangers they encounter in the underground. 


Who we are:  

Eric Swiz - Director


A graduate of NYU Film, over the past five years Eric Swiz has collected intensive first-hand experience in the worlds of narrative and documentary filmmaking as one of the primary creative influences of JAY Z’s Life+Times; directing, producing, filming, and editing over 100 short-form digital works, including short films, music videos, digital brand campaigns (Trapstar, McDonald’s, Fiat), and nationally broadcast television commercials (HBO, Sean John, Zoo York). Clients: JAY Z, Beyoncé, Leonardo DiCaprio, Dr. Sean “Diddy” Combs, HBO, Pharrell, Kate Upton, Rocawear, Fiat, McDonald’s, Justice, Haim, TDE, Freddie Gibbs, Macklemore, among others. Eric Swiz is a co-owner and founder of Scheme Engine.

Nathan Shapiro - Co-Producer

Nathan Shapiro is an actor, co-producer of Scenes From The Underground, and a founding partner of First Circle LLC. Nathan is a graduate of The William Esper Studio in New York, trained in The Meisner Technique. Past film credits include Good Dads (dir. Christian Stayton) and Scrapper (dir. Brady Hall, starring Michael Beach, Aidan Gillen), as well as numerous short films and pilots. Scenes From The Underground is his feature film production debut.

Jean-Raphael Ambron - Producer 

Jean-Raphael Ambron is producer and former partner of Act Zero Films.  He has extensive production experience on over fifty commercials, countless short films, and numerous music videos. His films have won multiple accolades including the “Prix de Jeunesse” from the Cannes Film Festival, the Grand Jury prize from the Black American Film Festival, and multiple selections at The Sundance Film Festival. In 2014 Jean-Raphael won an Emmy for Best Sport Documentary "Lost and Found: '73 Knicks Championship Tape.”

Smokey Nelson- Director of Photography 

Known for his work on such films as Half Nelson, Blue Valentine, and Cold Souls, Smokey’s work is marked by his keen attention to detail and unrelenting ingenuity, both of which are qualities essential to this film.

Andrew Justin Smith - Casting Director


Known for his work in the casting department on American Hustle and The Fighter, Andrew has assisted in assembling a diverse cast overflowing with raw New York talent.

The path from daydream to feature film hasn't been without its struggles, but it's been well worth it.  In just two years, we have:
  • Collected hundreds of stories from peoples real lives, subway musicians, dancers, MTA employees and police officers.
  • Auditioned hundreds of actors over the course of 18 months.
  • Recruited an incredible production and legal team.
  • Spent countless hours location scouting all five boroughs of New York City.
  • Penned a phenomenal script starring over fifty diverse characters, in collaboration with five amazing screenwriters.
  • Assembled an ensemble of local musicians to create an entirely original soundtrack.

And now, we need your help.

p. Noel Y.C.


What We Need 

We need to raise $65,000 to begin production of this film.  

  • Raising $65,000 will put us at the bare minimum we need to make this production.  That includes paying cast and crew, equipment rentals, location fees, and production expenses such as transportation and studio fees.
  • If contributors like you help us meet our goal, we will have enough funds to ensure we can shoot this film from start to finish.


The above breakdown represents just a portion of the costs involved in making this film.  Working in a professional New York environment is not easy, nor inexpensive, and especially so when considering a script with the ambition and scope of ours.  When you factor in post production services, proper city permitting, SAG bonds, and film insurance, to name a few, we've only just begun to tackle the costs necessary to make the film of our dreams, and one that will surely resonate with film audiences around the world.


What You Get

Check out the perks on the right, and refer to our FAQ at the bottom for more information.


The Impact

  •  It was incredibly important in creating this piece to feature perspectives normally relegated to the margins.  Therefore, it was essential our script feature actors of all genders/races/orientations.  By supporting this film, you help bring voice and multi-dimensionality to normally under-represented populations.  

  • Similarly, we wanted to make sure that these were all characters who would not appear out of place in an everyday commute.  With that in mind, we made the decision to forego the star-power of household names in favor of brilliant but lesser known actors, and to pay them industry standard wages. By supporting us, you help support the careers of up-and-coming talent.

  • This is not a film that has been done before.  This is not a superhero movie.  This is not a sequel.  This is new:  a challenging script from five different writers, taking place in a single day, with over fifty characters, speaking multiple languages, all within the confines of a shared public space.  If you're tired of seeing the same recycled stories, we hope you'll support us to create this new and challenging film.



Other Ways You Can Help

  • Stalk us on our website and through social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram).
  • Spread the word! Share this campaign with your friends.
Join us on this adventure into the world of the New York underground.  It's not the destination that defines us - it's what we discover in transit.


FAQ

General
  • Why Indiegogo?
  • What will you do if you raise more than your goal?
  • When will you make the film? When will it be released?
  • Is a studio agency running this campaign with you?
  • What happens if the movie never comes out?
Perks
  • What if the perk I want is sold out?
  • When will I receive my perks?
  • Are all rewards available in all countries?
  • How will you know where to send perks?
  • What if my address changes?
  • What if I want more than one perk?

www.SFTUfilm.com
story_txt:
Six million daily riders.
Six million stories.


Scenes From The Underground is a feature film that takes place almost entirely on the New York Subway system over the course of a single 24 hour period.  
With true stories compiled from interviews with hundreds of New Yorkers over the course of seven years, Scenes features a diverse cast of over fifty characters, all struggling with the challenges of everyday survival.
Whether they be tales of joy and sorrow, romance and heartbreak, or the mundane and the sublime, the paths of these New Yorkers will forever be changed by the friends and strangers they encounter in the underground. 








Who we are:  

Eric Swiz - Director 



A graduate of NYU Film, over the past five years Eric Swiz has collected intensive first-hand experience in the worlds of narrative and documentary filmmaking as one of the primary creative influences of JAY Z’s Life+Times; directing, producing, filming, and editing over 100 short-form digital works, including short films, music videos, digital brand campaigns (Trapstar, McDonald’s, Fiat), and nationally broadcast television commercials (HBO, Sean John, Zoo York). Clients: JAY Z, Beyoncé, Leonardo DiCaprio, Dr. Sean “Diddy” Combs, HBO, Pharrell, Kate Upton, Rocawear, Fiat, McDonald’s, Justice, Haim, TDE, Freddie Gibbs, Macklemore, among others. Eric Swiz is a co-owner and founder of Scheme Engine.

Nathan Shapiro - Co-Producer


Nathan Shapiro is an actor, co-producer of Scenes From The Underground, and a founding partner of First Circle LLC. Nathan is a graduate of The William Esper Studio in New York, trained in The Meisner Technique. Past film credits include Good Dads (dir. Christian Stayton) and Scrapper (dir. Brady Hall, starring Michael Beach, Aidan Gillen), as well as numerous short films and pilots. Scenes From The Underground is his feature film production debut.
Jean-Raphael Ambron - Producer 

Jean-Raphael Ambron is producer and former partner of Act Zero Films.  He has extensive production experience on over fifty commercials, countless short films, and numerous music videos. His films have won multiple accolades including the “Prix de Jeunesse” from the Cannes Film Festival, the Grand Jury prize from the Black American Film Festival, and multiple selections at The Sundance Film Festival. In 2014 Jean-Raphael won an Emmy for Best Sport Documentary "Lost and Found: '73 Knicks Championship Tape.”


Smokey Nelson- Director of Photography 

Known for his work on such films as Half Nelson, Blue Valentine, and Cold Souls, Smokey’s work is marked by his keen attention to detail and unrelenting ingenuity, both of which are qualities essential to this film.

Known for his work in the casting department on American Hustle and The Fighter, Andrew has assisted in assembling a diverse cast overflowing with raw New York talent.

Auditioned hundreds of actors over the course of 18 months.
Recruited an incredible production and legal team.
Spent countless hours location scouting all five boroughs of New York City.
Penned a phenomenal script starring over fifty diverse characters, in collaboration with five amazing screenwriters.
Assembled an ensemble of local musicians to create an entirely original soundtrack.

And now, we need your help.




p. Noel Y.C.



What We Need  We need to raise $65,000 to begin production of this film.    Raising $65,000 will put us at the bare minimum we need to make this production.  That includes paying cast and crew, equipment rentals, location fees, and production expenses such as transportation and studio fees. If contributors like you help us meet our goal, we will have enough funds to ensure we can shoot this film from start to finish.





The above breakdown represents just a portion of the costs involved in making this film.  Working in a professional New York environment is not easy, nor inexpensive, and especially so when considering a script with the ambition and scope of ours.  When you factor in post production services, proper city permitting, SAG bonds, and film insurance, to name a few, we've only just begun to tackle the costs necessary to make the film of our dreams, and one that will surely resonate with film audiences around the world.



What You Get


Check out the perks on the right, and refer to our FAQ at the bottom for more information.




   
The Impact
  It was incredibly important in creating this piece to feature perspectives normally relegated to the margins.  Therefore, it was essential our script feature actors of all genders/races/orientations.  By supporting this film, you help bring voice and multi-dimensionality to normally under-represented populations.  
Similarly, we wanted to make sure that these were all characters who would not appear out of place in an everyday commute.  With that in mind, we made the decision to forego the star-power of household names in favor of brilliant but lesser known actors, and to pay them industry standard wages. By supporting us, you help support the careers of up-and-coming talent. This is not a film that has been done before.  This is not a superhero movie.  This is not a sequel.  This is new:  a challenging script from five different writers, taking place in a single day, with over fifty characters, speaking multiple languages, all within the confines of a shared public space.  If you're tired of seeing the same recycled stories, we hope you'll support us to create this new and challenging film.









    Other Ways You Can Help  Stalk us on our website and through social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram). Spread the word! Share this campaign with your friends.
Join us on this adventure into the world of the New York underground.  It's not the destination that defines us - it's what we discover in transit.

Why Indiegogo?

What will you do if you raise more than your goal?

When will you make the film?  When will it be released?

Perks

story:
OVERVIEW

'The Kick' presents a great opportunity for you to get behind a team of talented individuals. What makes this project so great is the strong team of players along with the unique and refreshing story.  I think everyone involved would really appreciate having this project under their belt.

Production starts late August 2015 and will run till the beginning of September 2015 in Sydney, Australia.

The film is being geared towards an international film festival run in 2016.

SYNOPSIS

'The Kick' is a story of duplicity and deception, following the life of Roy, a charming pickpocket who falls for the beautiful Angela, one of his victims.

FUNDING

This is a passion project, so we will need resource so that we can accomplish the following:

- Secure appropriate locations
- Equipment and gear rental
- Assembling props and wardrobe
- Transportation & feeding of cast/crew

SOCIAL

Follow us for updates and behind the scenes on Facebook and Instagram

story:
WHY DONATE?

By donating you won't exactly be saving the world from impending vampire doom but you would be bringing us a little closer to making our horror/comedy vampire film a reality.

To us, that's pretty heroic.  Donating will also enable you to earn some amazing perks, including behind the scenes footage and photography, exclusive posters and the chance to attend a movie premier!

WHAT TO EXPECT 

Expect intense vampire vs slayer fight scenes, a whole lot of special effects, some blood and gore - all with a dash of British comedy. 

STORY

Vampire Slayers Bill and Jack, are celebrating the anniversary of their bromance when they are sent on a quest to destroy the evil Prince Viktor and stop a Vampire takeover of Earth. As Bill is pressured by his evil conscience to kill Viktor alone and win the legendary 'Golden Stake Award', Jack must prevent his inexperienced and cocky partner from making a dangerous decision that can threaten humanity's very existence.  

Will Bill give in to his ego? Will they stop Viktor's evil ambitions for the Living?

Without your support these questions will never be answered and the world will be controlled by creatures of the underworld. Please support our project, the world deserves a hero.

INSPIRATION AND VISION

The film is a Comedy/Horror/Adventure and has been inspired by a wide range of Classics, modern Vampire tales and Comedies. 
Our vision is a film that harks back to the kind of fantastical and over the top comedy adventures we used to watch as children, and a tribute to the Vampire subgenre - while also poking fun at it!
Since the film is to be partly shot at the iconic Ealing Studios, the UK's spiritual home for comedies, we couldn't resist giving people a film that would make them laugh out loud... and hopefully hide behind a pillow!
We were also driven to make a deeply personal story about family and friendship, and the dangers that the human ego can pose in certain situations, as Bill must overcome his inner demon to help Jack defeat Prince Viktor save the world from the Vampire Revolution!



And because the movie also contains fantastical adventure...


CREW

DIRECTOR - Max Aaron
PRODUCER - Lisa Maxton
CINEMATOGRAPHER - Anna Dushenkina
EXECUTIVE PRODUCERS - MetFilm

story:
This is a story about a real life actress with a real family who wanted to make a funny, dramatic show about a fictional actress and her fictional family. So for a long time we wrote and rewrote and shot and reshot on our own dime. Sometimes a little less than a dime. And passionate actors and actresses joined the project and believed the material was worth the constant grind. Of course they were right. And here we are with the biggest and best script to officially launch the series, Whatever It Takes. Imagine if Modern Family and Ugly Betty had a love child and it ran off and eloped with Shameless. That's this show. A show about family and choosing to go your own way even as circumstances pull you back home.

But let's go back to the beginning...  This trailer is a mashup of scenes from the original WIT pilot and some other scenes that were shot only to promote the series.

After a little heartache and a lot of determination we put together a  show from a comedy script that was actually for an episode later in the series...

That brings us to the present... and why we want you to become part of the WIT  family.

JOHANNA TOLENTINO 

She's Rosaly Rojo, the aspiring actress who made it all the way to Hollywood only to discover her New Jersey family still needed her. While RoRo's still figuring out what she wants in life and love everybody expects her to have all the answers.


ELAINE DEL VALLE

She's Lucy Rojo, a devoted but unconventional mom, and a struggling alcoholic. She's closest to her sister Rosaly and is the first to defend her family, usually with a bat.


BRIAN A. WILSON

As tough as ex-cop and boxing coach Birdie Johnson is, he's just a big softie around Lucy. But how can he woo her when he's forced to use her cousin, Carlos in a corrupt plan to save his failing gym?


BLANCA CAMACHO

Queen of the Rojo family, Sofy is a silent but strong figure whose home is her castle.  But when her brother in law challenges her in the kitchen she declares open war.


EDDIE ROSARIO

Rafael Rojo lays down the law as stern father and role model. Once a musician, he abandoned his passion to support his family and counsels his son Carlos to do the same. 

 JAY ALVAREZ

Meet Manny Rojo, perpetually unemployed, a Food Network hopeful. Who's competitiveness with Sofy in the kitchen threatens to boil over into culinary chaos. 
 


GABE VARGAS

Carlos Rojo is an up and coming boxer who manages to stay out of hot water outside Birdie's gym. But when troubles start to follow him inside the ring he has to hatch a plan to fight his way out.

SOLANYI RODRIGUEZ

She's Dayanara Rojo, a confident man-eater secretly envious of Rosaly's independence, barreling through a parade of inappropriate dates to find the one love even she doesn't realize she needs.


PHIL JOHN

A big schemer... uh...dreamer and a petty thief, Chato is the warm and funny adopted member of the Rojos. There are more layers to Chato than just being a jokester; we see those layers  unfold as the series continues.

GINA TUTTLE

Raised in a family of  hippies, April Rane is Rosaly's upbeat New York talent agent whose most famous client is a balding twelve year old actor divorcing his parents to lay claim to a potential phone app fortune.

A.B. LUGO

Frandie is Rosaly's best friend who tells it like it is, especially when she doesn't want to hear it. Frandie dreams of seeing his name on a marquee one day.


MARCOS SOTOMAYOR

When Henry and Dayanara get together he thinks he's found the one, but his competitiveness with Carlos in the boxing gym may mean he has to fight for more than her affection.


JOCELYN MARTINEZ

Jennifer Martin is beautiful, educated abroad and classy, But when her social worker boyfriend falls for Rosaly, the gloves come off and Rosaly remembers her when she was just Jennifer Martinez, the school bully.


That's the ensemble cast so far with others to be added. But what a cast. Johanna Tolentino (Creed, El Pasaje, Lean on Me) pulls triple duty as lead actor, co-writer and executive producer; Brian is a veteran actor of HBO's hit, The Wire; Elaine Del Valle (Donnie Brasco, Brownsville Bred) and Jay Alvarez (Be Careful, The Sharks Will Eat You) are the creators of their own acclaimed off-Broadway shows.  Blanca Camacho (The Secret Life of Walter Mitty) was an original cast member of the Tony Award winning musical, In The Heights. The credits for the entire cast go on and on and we can't wait to show you what they can do. Here's how you can help.


GET "WIT" IT!

So far we have put together a number of short videos, getting as feeling for the unique characters and the storyline. Now we want to go deeper and shoot a series length pilot, as heartfelt as it is funny just like the families we love.

Donations will go towards paying and feeding our large cast, the crew, locations and post production including editing, color correction and music licensing. We expect to be able to shoot two 22 minute episodes with the amount you will help us raise. 


But we would never ask you to help us and get nothing in return, which is why we're offering WIT specific gifts to say thanks. These perks include an exclusive DVD including bonus footage and hilarious outtakes, an original script signed by the cast,  a premium soft t-shirt (below),


  Whatever it Takes exclusive t-shirt

RoRo's home cooked Puerto Rican dinner with the cast, big shot executive producer credit, and many more perks just for you.

And whatever donation you choose to give will be well spent since this campaign gives us the ability to put every dollar we raise to good use.


So here it is, your chance to support independent production; a funny engaging series that started as one person's passion and grew into a team of dedicated creators and performers .  

If you liked what you saw so far donate and help make the next step the biggest yet. Even if you can't contribute you can still help. Spread the word now on Twitter, Facebook, and all your social media platforms.

And stay tuned, because in a few weeks we'll show you a special behind the scenes spoof documentary to further introduce you to our cast.

Thanks for your support.

  Whatever it Takes exclusive t-shirt
RoRo's home cooked Puerto Rican dinner with the cast, big shot executive producer credit, and many more perks just for you.
And whatever donation you choose to give will be well spent since this campaign gives us the ability to put every dollar we raise to good use.

story:
Please check the update about this campaign.

THE STORY

I teach a service-learning class at VCU, partnered with the James River Park System. This class is a first-year seminar, and I use service projects as a way to get students out of the classroom into the community. In this case, we go to the park (all around, up and down) to think, talk, work, reflect on civic responsibility, pro-action, wild spaces in urban places, discovery, utility - you name it.

During the year we work in the park and provide whatever help is needed. Over the course of the class, we have have installed markers, painted miles of wood and metal, diverted trails or dug pits - even caught a thief. It’s been a great experience; I do have stories.


This is one of them:

A couple years ago, we pitched to the park system the idea of a “Memorial Bike Rack” – a sculpted object which also provides a utility. The bike rack honors those prisoners of war held on Belle Isle during the Civil War, as well as provide a place to secure bikes. People stash their bikes anywhere right now, because there just aren’t enough bike racks to handle the traffic.

The shape is modeled on the Sibley tents provided for the prisoners in the camp. It is conical; a one-and-a-half foot diameter center ring at the top is supported by eight long legs. Twelve feet tall and eighteen feet across at the base, these tents were prominent features of the early prison camp.


As the Civil War raged, living conditions on Belle Isle deteriorated. Tents degraded; shelter disappeared. Exposure contributed to the deaths of thousands of prisoners.

Ralph White, the Park Manager at the time, really liked the idea, gave us the go-ahead, then retired. The project had to pause until the new Park Manager, Nathan Burrell, was settled.  I kept the project as a part of my class during the interim. A park system with near a million active visitors a year and without a lot of bike racks (let alone memorials to the Union soldiers kept in inhumane conditions) seemed to need the project. I used the parts of the process of making this memorial bike rack as avenues for experiential research and writing, composition and design. As we learned, the project progressed: figuring out how to make what, what materials needed to be gotten, who to supply it, fabricate it, assemble it.

As we searched out all parts of the creation and execution of a Memorial Bike Rack, we also explored the larger Richmond community – this class is a first year seminar, so most of the students hadn’t been in Richmond very long, some having been just in-country for a few weeks. Working on the project, students discovered there’s more to this city here - a lot more (a whole lot more) than what's just on campus. The class went places we wouldn’t have otherwise.

The Belle Isle Memorial Bike Rack was installed on Belle Isle December 6, 2014. The final part of installing the piece was to coat it in some sort of black rubber paint, to disappear from peripheral vision, but still it caught your eye. The day it got put in, people started using it. After that, when I went to Belle Isle, I would see bikes at it or kids on it.


Three months later, it was ripped down by some assholes and tossed in the James River.

Here’s my idea: make more. Make more better and stronger.


THE IDEA

I would like to build and install a series of four sculpted bike racks which interpret the experience of the Civil War prison camp on Belle Isle. The series will be a collaboration between local artists, the park system, and sponsors.

I’d like to get it installed before the 2015 UCI Road World Championships in September.

Any images associated with the project at this point represent just working designs.


Four bike racks will make the series – one to represent each year the prison camp operated on Belle Isle (1862 to 1865). The first one will be a model of a Sibley tent, twelve feet tall and eighteen feet wide at the base (the same as the Memorial Bike Rack). Each bike rack after the first is successively more “broken” or “degraded” – 1863 has a full kink, 1864 is a mess, 1865 folds in on itself. In series, this illustrates the worsening conditions of the camp and of the prisoners. The final iteration is the most recognizable as a bike rack: the top center ring will have collapsed in to the point of being on the ground in the center of the wide base offering many places along its legs to secure a bike.

Each bike rack will have a unique sign describing the real conditions by a real prisoner of the camp for a particular year. Two additional signs – one at the Lee Bridge walkway overlook and one at the Bike Skills park – will explain the series and list sponsors.


THE PLAN

Like the Memorial Rack, the Interpretive Series will be assembled on Belle Isle, under the roof of the remains of the Old Dominion Nail Factory and Manufactury. The project is based on the process of creating and executing the Memorial Bike Rack. The materials will be moved to the warehouse. The area of each rack in the series will be  surveyed, and the path for moving the pieces policed for impediments. Under the warehouse roof, the series will be laid out, put together generally. Outside, the bases will be secured with concrete. The pieces will then be finished, forms completed. The pieces are then moved from the warehouse to location and secured to a base. At the conclusion of the installation will be a dedication.

The fact that the Memorial Bike Rack was destroyed only makes this project stronger: foremost, some modifications (involving more concrete) improve the base and stability and security of the racks. Some design details emphasize now more its function as a bike rack; discoveries from local archives continue to provide more insight into the prisoners’ lives.


THE MONEY

The series needs $24,000 to complete.

I would like to install the series on Belle Isle prior to the 2015 UCI Road World Championships. To reasonably expect to complete this project by that time,  funding needs to be secured by mid-August 2015.

I have partnered with the Friends of the James River Park System, a 501(c)(3) non-profit entity. Support and donations to the project are to the Friends of the James River Park System and are therefore tax-deductible. Any amount achieved above this $24,000 goal will go to the Friends of the James River Park System for other projects at their discretion.

The $24,000 figure estimates foreseeable exigencies, reasonable market fluctuations and worst-case scenario estimates. It’s based on the cost of creating and executing the Memorial Bike Rack. Essentially, the money is used for materials, manufacturing, fabrication, and signage. Everything will be locally sourced, contracted, and engaged.


THAT'S IT

I believe this is a good community project to install before the 2015 UCI Road World Championship to show the world something else of Richmond.

I need $24,000 to install this series of bike racks which interpret the experience of the prison camp on Belle Isle, providing an active memorial to prisoners of war incarcerated in there.

I invite any donation or support for this project. If you can’t donate, you can support: I can take on as many people as reasonably need to be for a project of this size, materials can also be donated. I can involve students with this, for as long as it takes, providing a very unique project-based learning experience - an original form of education of this place. 

And you can tell others about this project. Spread the word!
story_txt:
Please check the update about this campaign.THE STORYI teach a service-learning class
at VCU, partnered with the James River Park System. This class is a first-year
seminar, and I use service projects as a way to get students out of the classroom into the community. In this case, we go to the park (all around, up and down) to
think, talk, work, reflect on civic responsibility, pro-action, wild spaces in urban places, discovery, utility - you name it. During the year we work in the park and
provide whatever help is needed. Over the course of the class, we have have installed
markers, painted miles of wood and metal, diverted trails or dug pits - even
caught a thief. It’s been a great experience;
I do have stories.
This is one of them:
A couple years ago, we pitched to
the park system the idea of a “Memorial Bike Rack” – a sculpted object which
also provides a utility. The bike rack honors those prisoners of war held on
Belle Isle during the Civil War, as well as provide a place to secure bikes. People stash their
bikes anywhere right now, because there just aren’t enough bike racks to handle
the traffic.
The shape is modeled on the
Sibley tents provided for the prisoners in the camp. It is conical; a one-and-a-half foot diameter center ring at the top is supported by eight long legs. Twelve feet tall and eighteen feet across at the base, these tents were
prominent features of the early prison camp. As the Civil War raged, living
conditions on Belle Isle deteriorated. Tents degraded; shelter disappeared.
Exposure contributed to the deaths of thousands of prisoners. 
Ralph White, the Park Manager at
the time, really liked the idea, gave us the go-ahead, then retired. The
project had to pause until the new Park Manager, Nathan Burrell, was settled.  I kept the project as a part of my class during the
interim. A
park system with near a million active visitors a year and without a lot of bike
racks (let alone memorials to the Union soldiers kept in inhumane conditions)
seemed to need the project. I used the parts of the process of making this memorial bike rack as
avenues for experiential research and writing, composition and design. As we learned, the project progressed: figuring out how to make what, what
materials needed to be gotten, who to supply it, fabricate it, assemble it. 
As we searched out all parts of
the creation and execution of a Memorial Bike Rack, we also explored
the larger Richmond community – this class is a first year seminar, so most of
the students hadn’t been in Richmond very long, some having been just in-country
for a few weeks. Working on the project,
students discovered there’s more to this city here - a lot more (a whole lot more) than what's just on campus. The
class went places we wouldn’t have otherwise.
The Belle Isle Memorial Bike Rack
was installed on Belle Isle December 6, 2014. The final part of installing the
piece was to coat it in some sort of black rubber paint, to disappear from
peripheral vision, but still it caught your eye. The day it got put in, people
started using it. After that, when I went to Belle Isle, I would see bikes at
it or kids on it.
Three months later, it was ripped
down by some assholes and tossed in the James River.
Here’s my idea: make more. Make more better and stronger.THE IDEAI would like to build and install a series of four sculpted bike racks which interpret the experience of the Civil War
prison camp on Belle Isle. The series will be a collaboration between local artists,
the park system, and sponsors.
I’d like to get it installed
before the 2015 UCI Road World Championships in September.
Any images
associated with the project at this point represent just working
designs.
Four bike racks
will make the series – one to represent each year the prison camp operated on
Belle Isle (1862 to 1865). The first one will be a model of a Sibley tent,
twelve feet tall and eighteen feet wide at the base (the same as the
Memorial Bike Rack). Each bike rack after the first is successively more
“broken” or “degraded” – 1863 has a full kink, 1864 is a mess, 1865 folds in on
itself. In series, this illustrates the worsening conditions of the camp and of
the prisoners. The final iteration is the most recognizable as a bike rack: the
top center ring will have collapsed in to the point of being on the ground in
the center of the wide base offering many places along its legs to
secure a bike.
Each bike rack
will have a unique sign describing the real conditions by a real prisoner of
the camp for a particular year. Two additional signs – one at the Lee Bridge
walkway overlook and one at the Bike Skills park – will explain the series and list sponsors.
THE PLAN
Like the Memorial Rack, the Interpretive Series will
be assembled on Belle Isle, under the roof of the remains of the Old Dominion
Nail Factory and Manufactury. The project is based on the process of creating
and executing the Memorial Bike Rack. The materials will be moved to the
warehouse. The area of each rack in the series will be  surveyed, and the path for moving the pieces
policed for impediments. Under the warehouse roof, the series will be laid out,
put together generally. Outside, the bases will be secured with concrete. The pieces
will then be finished, forms completed. The pieces are then moved from the
warehouse to location and secured to a base. At the conclusion of the
installation will be a dedication.
The fact that the Memorial Bike Rack was destroyed only makes this project stronger: foremost, some modifications (involving more
concrete) improve the base and stability and security of the racks. Some design details emphasize
now more its function as a bike rack; discoveries from local archives continue
to provide more insight into the prisoners’ lives.
THE MONEY
The series needs $24,000 to
complete. 
I would like to
install the series on Belle Isle prior to the 2015 UCI Road
World Championships. To
reasonably expect to complete this project by that time,  funding needs to be
secured by mid-August 2015. 
I have partnered with the Friends
of the James River Park System, a 501(c)(3) non-profit entity. Support and
donations to the project are to the Friends of the James River Park System and are therefore tax-deductible. Any amount achieved above this $24,000
goal will go to the Friends of the James River Park System for other projects at their
discretion. 
The $24,000 figure estimates foreseeable
exigencies, reasonable market fluctuations and worst-case scenario estimates. It’s
based on the cost of creating and executing the Memorial Bike Rack. Essentially,
the money is used for materials, manufacturing, fabrication, and signage.
Everything will be locally sourced, contracted, and engaged.

project to install before the 2015 UCI Road World Championship to
show the world something else of Richmond.

of bike racks which interpret the experience of the prison camp on Belle Isle, providing
an active memorial to prisoners of war incarcerated in there.I invite any
donation or support for this project. If you can’t donate, you can support: I
can take on as many people as reasonably need to be for a project of this size, materials can also be donated. I
can involve students with this, for as long as it takes, providing a very unique
project-based learning experience - an original form of education of this place. And you can tell others about this project. Spread the word!

story:
Welcome to Bite Club....

It has begun! Pre-production is well under way for Bite Club. Inspired by my love for films like Underworld, Blade, X-Men and TV shows True Blood and Being Human. Bite Club is a supernatural action film based and shot in Brisbane. Working with a limited budget and a hardworking and talented crew and cast, we want to deliver a great film that entertains. This is the first instalment of a 3 part series of Bite Club, together the 3 parts will be the length of a feature film. Our passion and eagerness is what drives us to think outside the proverbial box. We hope you can join us in our journey and support us any way you can. - Kim, Writer and Director.

Bite Club : Part One begins with young werewolf Adron who decides to leave home to look for his missing older brother Haydon. Adron has never really seen the darker underground world these supernaturals delve in. He begins his search by going to the last place his brother was seen. The legendary underground venue Bite Club run by sleazy vampire Caius. What Adron doesn't realize is that his simple action has catapulted a chain of events that will start a war.

Bite Club has demons, werewolves, vampires, and more mysterious beings! Based and shot in Brisbane, Australia. These supernaturals are not your typical Hollywood cliches.. they are more evolved to blend in with humans, less animalistic and even weaker. But for those who crave to be "themselves", Bite Club is the place to be.

We have an amazing crew and cast involved and we are super super keen to begin shooting in August! We want to show you what we can do!!

A taste of our storyboard.


plus many many more!! Please see our Facebook page for all the updated info!

Why we need your help

As with many film productions, it is quite costly. We would love your support in helping us travel along this journey!

So far we have most of the equipment and locations locked in and paid for. This is where your contributions count. By showing your support and donating you'll be helping with the following!
- feeding the cast & crew
- set design
- props
- MUA/SFX expenses
- costumes
- post production

$5000 will greatly support us making this film, but it doesn't stop there.
The MORE we raise the bigger and better the
- sets
- costumes
- stunts
- fight scenes
- post production
can be, there is no limitation on imagination with these areas! Also we want to look after our cast and crew who are giving us their precious time to help make this an amazing movie! 
Every little bit helps. Your support is valuable to us and we appreciate it!!
If you cannot donate please show your support by sharing and liking our Facebook Page and video. 
Find us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram

story:
About the Film

In the near future, an unexplained phenomenon has progressively given the majority of the world's population telepathic abilities. While many herald this as a new age of human evolution and culture, for those who do not have this gift, this new world is a dark place. The non-telepathic have become the new under-class, with new laws and social change making them less than human.

Alina is a young woman who has not developed telepathic abilities. Under the new 'Reclamation' laws, Alina is case managed by a telepathic social worker named Ash. Through their interview, we learn Alina's story and the discrimination she has faced through her life.

In this piece, we examine the nature of discrimination. How those in power can justify their feelings of superiority and the social (and often legal) barriers that put up to keep others down. They believe they are doing the right thing, but discrimination is never right.


About the Director

A lifelong cinephile and lover of story, Dave Cairns directed his first film in 2000, bringing together his love of drama and photography to form Marley’s Ghost Productions. In the fifteen years, Dave has directed numerous short films and won several awards for writing and directing. In addition to his work with Marley’s Ghost, in 2011 Dave became the producer and director of Salvo Studios, the media production unit of The Salvation Army in southern Australia.

Dave has a passion and commitment to film as a tool of personal and social challenge, firmly believing that the stories and characters of film can tell us something of the truth of our world and ourselves.


About the Producer

Ben Whimpey directed his first film at 7 years of age using LEGO pirate men as actors. He still has the film and considers those LEGO men to be some of the most talented actors he’s worked with. Twenty five years on, Ben is a partner of Indimax Productions and has a bank of successful projects to his name spanning films and documentaries.

Ben is committed to producing high quality and profitable entertainment and trying to ensure that the artists he works with get that most elusive of artistic rewards: A paycheck. Ben has completed his Post Graduate Degree in Producing and Masters in Screen Arts and Business with the prestigious AFTRS.


About the Production

In this production, we have managed to bring together a talented team of actors, designers and filmmakers to bring the world of 'Telepathy' to life. Science fiction affords filmmakers the ability to look at the world in a universal way. To tell a story that everyone can see themselves in. Be it those who feel that loneliness and oppression, or those who are challenged by their know bigotry. It is that quality of applicability that we hope will enable 'Telepathy' to have a positive social impact. But it's not all about social impact, we are also looking to showcase the talents of several emerging filmmakers and actors, presenting the next generation of the Australian film industry.

Our primary hope for the release of 'Telepathy' is to have it screen at several high profile film festivals. We feel that the talent and the subject matter will make it appealing fetsival organiser in various place around the world. Beyond this, we aim to make 'Telepathy' available online, as well as release a special edition Blu-ray and DVD.


About the Budget

Most of the team are working for free because they are passionate about this project as well as making a great film. However there are costs that we cannot avoid and if we are able to pay these the film will be stronger as a result.
Here is a basic breakdown of the actual investment we would like to be able to make into the film with your support:
Location Permits/Fees - $1950
(We've managed to get access to some great locations that will create a real world)
Cast - $3250
(We have some amazing actors lined up!)
Art Department - $2000
(It is, after all, a sci-fi film, and good sci-fi means a great Art Department)
Wardrobe - $500
(You'll be amazed what our Wardrobe person can achieve with this little)
Catering - $800
(We want to feed all crew and cast for the 5 days of production)
Equipment Hire - $1750
(We have access to a great camera but this will allow us to hire cinematic lenses and other lighting equipment)
Film Festival entry fees - $750
(To get the word out)
TOTAL: $11,000


About You

You may not be a director, or designer, or actor, but can be a part of the filmmaking experience. By contributing to this film, you can invest into the emerging film industry in Australia and help to tell this important story. On this page, you can find the perks you'll receive by contributing, which will give you a piece of 'Telepathy.'

You can also help by sharing this campaign on social media, inviting your friends and family to join with you. We rely on people like you to get the word out about projects like this, because it's only through community support that films like 'Telepathy' are possible.

You can also because of the Facebook group (/telepathyfilm) or follow us on Instagram and Twitter (/marleysghostpro). That way, you can keep up-to-date with all the stages of 'Telepathy' production.

story:
This campaign is about a really cool project and product. A patent pending reusable firecracker. By choosing a "perk", you are are buying and I’m selling you one of those products. That’s what my crowdfunding campaign is all about... you get something really cool for your money.

You can find a limited quantity of M58 Six Packs or single M650h's for only $78.00 and free shipping within the continental United States.


Welcome to the world of the first aesthetic pyrotechnic: A sustainable ultra modern firework, milled from solid 416 stainless steel.


Short Summary

Fireworks were invented in China in the 7th century. Not much has changed about them, until now. Welcome to the world of the first aesthetic pyrotechnic: A sustainable ultra modern firework, milled from solid 416 stainless steel.

Elegantly simple in its design, the user fills the reusable firework with widely available black powder, inserts a fuse, gently packs the powder down with the included tamper, and it’s ready to make a big boom. After use, the firework is easily 

 cleaned, and it's even dishwasher safe! The M-series firework comes in two sizes: the M58 cracker and the M650 boom. 


What I Need

The funding for this project will provide for the infrastructure that will enable this reusable firework and other future projects. Like the mC4d, the latest of the M 

Series firework line: A modern CNC machined  6061 aluminum container holding four M58f-crackers and a single tamper.


What You Get

You get a precision-machined sculpture that looks great year-round, just sitting on your desk or in your living room. On special occasions or just for fun, you can fill it with readily available, locally sourced black powder and it makes a very big boom. 


The Tech Specs

M650a, h and mf

Made of 416 stainless steel, 5 inches tall, 2.5 inches in diameter. Weighs in at over 5 pounds with a solid 6061 aluminum loading tamper and holds up to 650 grains of black powder. The M650a stands at a 68.2 degree angle, M650h is the straight model, the M650mf a massively scaled up exact replica of the M58f-cracker and capable of holding over 11 times the powder.

M58f

 

Made of 416 stainless steel, 2 inches tall, 1 inch in diameter. Sandblasted or tumbled finish, includes 6061 loading tamper and holds up to 58 grains of black powder or a single 50 grain preformed pellet.

mC4d

Milled from a solid block of 6061 aluminum, the sandblasted finished 3 inch ultra modern cube container holds 4 x M58f - crackers + one 6061 loading tamper.


The Goal

The goal for this project is $14,700. That includes the minimum down payment needed for a dedicated CNC machine. In addition, your contribution will pay for the raw materials for the initial manufacturing run.


The Perks


The Impact

Besides providing a lot of fun for you, the funder, these are the positive impacts of this project:

• One or more decently paying jobs

• A clean, sustainable, small-scale manufacturing 

• Future projects constrained only by imagination!

I’m not looking to be the next bazillionaire or to save the planet. I’m just looking to create a sustainable business and a positive work experience for a few people in this rural area, including myself. Ultimately, I’m taking this entire project off-grid and powering with solar.


Risks & Challenges

At whatever level of funding, even if it’s less than my stated goal, I will use the investment toward creation of the M factory. If only minimal levels of investment are achieved, I may have to locally outsource the first run of reusable firework devices.

The shipping times shown are estimates, based on a moderate degree of success in funding. Shipping times may be longer if pledges exceed estimates. As the project develops, I’ll be clear about time frames. If the funding goals are surpassed in a huge way, there will be some impact on delivery times for later donors. Manufacturing will occur on a first come, first served basis.

I encourage the user to check local and mail order retailers for availability of black powder. Even without black powder, the M series firework devices are awesome sculptures with aesthetic attitude.


Other Ways You Can Help

I appreciate any size donation, and you’ll really help me out by telling your friends and family about this project. Feel free to email me with any ideas you have to help this campaign or to contribute in any way,  e.g. internet marketing and other ways of getting the word out. Find and share my project at these links.

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/blackboxindustries.us

Google+: https://plus.google.com/u/0/1166643808129280882...

Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCu6pBcoR8pQa2F...

Pinterest: https://www.pinterest.com/pin/520025088201037883/

Twitter: https://twitter.com/BlackBoxInd

Tumbler: http://dlulek.tumblr.com


Thanks

I am proud and grateful to be a part of this community of folks who make 

cooperative funding happen. To you (the supporters of this project) and to all the folks at IndieGoGo, thank you.

Thank you from the future, from the company that will be known as Blackbox Industries LLC.

Series firework line: A modern CNC machined  6061 aluminum container holding four M58f-crackers and a single tamper.

What You Get

You get a precision-machined sculpture that looks great year-round, just sitting on your desk or in your living room. On special occasions or just for fun, you can fill it with readily available, locally sourced black powder and it makes a very big boom. 







The Tech Specs

M650a, h and mf


Made of 416 stainless steel, 5 inches tall, 2.5 inches in diameter. Weighs in at over 5 pounds with a solid 6061 aluminum loading tamper and holds up to 650 grains of black powder. The M650a stands at a 68.2 degree angle, M650h is the straight model, the M650mf a massively scaled up exact replica of the M58f-cracker and capable of holding over 11 times the powder.



M58f
 
Made of 416 stainless steel, 2 inches tall, 1 inch in diameter. Sandblasted or tumbled finish, includes 6061 loading tamper and holds up to 58 grains of black powder or a single 50 grain preformed pellet.


mC4d




Milled from a solid block of 6061 aluminum, the sandblasted finished 3 inch ultra modern cube container holds 4 x M58f - crackers + one 6061 loading tamper.






The Goal

The goal for this project is $14,700. That includes the minimum down payment needed for a dedicated CNC machine. In addition, your contribution will pay for the raw materials for the initial manufacturing run.

The Perks























The Impact
Besides providing a lot of fun for you, the funder, these are the positive impacts of this project:
• One or more decently paying jobs
• A clean, sustainable, small-scale manufacturing 
• Future projects constrained only by imagination!
I’m not looking to be the next bazillionaire or to save the planet. I’m just looking to create a sustainable business and a positive work experience for a few people in this rural area, including myself. Ultimately, I’m taking this entire project off-grid and powering with solar.


Risks & Challenges
At whatever level of funding, even if it’s less than my stated goal, I will use the investment toward creation of the M factory. If only minimal levels of investment are achieved, I may have to locally outsource the first run of reusable firework devices.
The shipping times shown are estimates, based on a moderate degree of success in funding. Shipping times may be longer if pledges exceed estimates. As the project develops, I’ll be clear about time frames. If the funding goals are surpassed in a huge way, there will be some impact on delivery times for later donors. Manufacturing will occur on a first come, first served basis.
I encourage the user to check local and mail order retailers for availability of black powder. Even without black powder, the M series firework devices are awesome sculptures with aesthetic attitude.


Other Ways You Can Help
 

I appreciate any size donation, and you’ll really help me out by telling your friends and family about this project. Feel free to email me with any ideas you have to help this campaign or to contribute in any way,  e.g. internet marketing and other ways of getting the word out. Find and share my project at these links.
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/blackboxindustries.us
Google+: https://plus.google.com/u/0/1166643808129280882...
Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCu6pBcoR8pQa2F...
Pinterest: https://www.pinterest.com/pin/520025088201037883/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/BlackBoxInd
Tumbler: http://dlulek.tumblr.com

Thanks
I am proud and grateful to be a part of this community of folks who make 


cooperative funding happen. To you (the supporters of this project) and to all the folks at IndieGoGo, thank you.




Thank you from the future, from the company that will be known as Blackbox Industries LLC.

story:
SHORT SUMMARY

Our team includes years of expertise in film and entertainment.  Members of Unlimited Creations have co produced movies on Netflix, award winning festival films, a film with an Oscar winning actor, and movies that have been translated into 12 different languages.



The hero of the movie is in a wheelchair- a very unusual and special kind of hero.


The hero in the wheelchair gets the girl at the end.  This story redefines who can be a romantic lead. 



This campaign is for an incredible story that deserves to be seen by audiences.  Everyone who reads the script can't put it down. 



This movie deals with important issues.

What We Need & What You Get

Breakdown:
  • We need basic funding for necessities like vehicle gas, food, insurance, and editing.
  • We want to include all contributors in the production, including screen time as background actors!
  • This movie is getting made.  We are finishers. 

The Impact

Your contribution will make a difference:
  • This project is valuable to the world because it shows a new kind of hero.
  • We have finished every project we have ever started.
  • You get to help create a feature film.  Your name will be credited!

Risks & Challenges

The only real risk is not finishing the movie.  If you are able to help us we will make sure that the film will reach the largest number of people that must see this film.  The challenge is that there are a number of stalkers in the world and we must expose their thinking, their craziness, to the innocent girls that can become their victims.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our movie.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
