story:
About the Writer/Director

Hi to all!
My name is Rachel Renee, a 29 year old, near future graduate of Los Angeles Film School. What got me into film production was not only my love for movies, but also my love for creation. My passion has always been telling stories either through words on a page or with pictures. When I realized I had the potential to bring my stories to life through film, I jumped at the opportunity. 

My style of writing has developed into a combination of drama, thriller and sci-fi. What can I say...I love the weird and freaky stuff. I write stories that either make your head spin or make you question your worth as a human being. Hot topics for me are anything that has to do with our progress and/or failures as humans or the internal psyche and the troubles that plague us.

Adam's Ale the Move

Adam's Ale is dramatic thriller about a couple, Adam and Bernadette who are living in Los Angeles, year 2030. Due to severe draught across the nation many cities face tough restrictions and water is under strict government control. After Adam makes a rebellious mistake to use more than his share, the couple are put on probation, leaving them with the decision to stay in the city or risk crossing the vast and dangerous desert to find hope and a new home. 

As stated in the overview of the project, I wrote Adam's Ale as a piece for advocating water conservation. Living in California as a transplant, I've come to realize how terrible the drought really is. Truthfully, the severity of the drought didn't hit me, until recently taking a trip across California. Many of the lakes are gone; most are mere swamps and mud puddles. Rivers have become dry rock beds. The sad part is that the drought is not only affecting Southern California, but many surrounding areas as well. The desert is growing. 

By supporting Adam's Ale, you are not just helping us create a successful thesis project, but helping to spread the word about the importance of water conservation and advocate global change. 

I believe I speak for my cast and crew when I say thank you for your support in this project. 

Want to be a part of the project? Here's how you can help.

Currently, Adam's Ale is in the pre-production stage. It is projected that we will move into production the second week of January then on to post-production in February. All the donations gained from this campaign will provide us with the resources to do many things. For the Art Department, we need props, set decoration, and wardrobe. We need to cover general costs such as permits, insurance and meals for our cast and crew. Also, we would like to make this project special by bringing in a composer to create a unique score for the film as well as hire and singer/songwriter to write a song for the end credits of the film. Lastly, it is our goal to submit this short film to Film Festivals across the country.

Fortunately, our school has provided us with part of our budget, as well as equipment and one film location, but we are still lacking. Your donations will help us bridge the gap so we can turn this project from a student film, into a meaningful and professional work of art.

In return for your support, we have created many perks as our way of thanking you. Some of them include t-shirts bearing our Tree of Life logo, handcrafted and unique Tree of Life Pendants, movie posters signed by the cast and having your name credited in the movie as a supporter. For a complete and detailed list of perks, please check out the perks page!

If for some reason we don't reach our goal, whatever proceeds we have made will be split between providing meals to our cast and crew and production design. Whatever is left, if any, will go to post-production.

Risks & Challenges

If you know film production, you know that things ALWAYS go wrong on set. What counteracts that is the crew, organization of the producer and crew leadership, and the effectiveness of the director. Fortunately, I feel that we have a great team. I have worked with most of the crew members and I know that they put everything they have into their work. Not only that, but we have the full support of Los Angeles Film School as well as fantastic instructors there to guide us through until the end. 

The only challenges that I foresee is being able to fund the needs of the Art Department. Many things can lower the production value of a film, but one of the biggest is production design. Within this project, there are things that we have to have. Fortunately however, we have some pretty frugal and creative members of our art department team. Even if we don't completely reach our goal and are only able to buy the necessities, I know that we can figure out alternative ways to achieve what we desire for the look of the film. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The biggest way you can help us to achieve our campaign goal is to spread the word. Please like and share our social media pages. We currently have Facebook and Instagram, but will be adding Twitter and Youtube very soon. We'll be posting our progress regularly so be sure to follow us. We are extremely excited to share this project with you. 

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/adamsalemovie/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/AdamsAletheMovie/
story_txt:
About the Writer/Director
Hi to all!My name is Rachel Renee, a 29 year old, near future graduate of Los Angeles Film School. What got me into film production was not only my love for movies, but also my love for creation. My passion has always been telling stories either through words on a page or with pictures. When I realized I had the potential to bring my stories to life through film, I jumped at the opportunity. 
My style of writing has developed into a combination of drama, thriller and sci-fi. What can I say...I love the weird and freaky stuff. I write stories that either make your head spin or make you question your worth as a human being. Hot topics for me are anything that has to do with our progress and/or failures as humans or the internal psyche and the troubles that plague us.
Adam's Ale the Move
Adam's Ale is dramatic thriller about a couple, Adam and Bernadette who are living in Los Angeles, year 2030. Due to severe draught across the nation many cities face tough restrictions and water is under strict government control. After Adam makes a rebellious mistake to use more than his share, the couple are put on probation, leaving them with the decision to stay in the city or risk crossing the vast and dangerous desert to find hope and a new home. 
As stated in the overview of the project, I wrote Adam's Ale as a piece for advocating water conservation. Living in California as a transplant, I've come to realize how terrible the drought really is. Truthfully, the severity of the drought didn't hit me, until recently taking a trip across California. Many of the lakes are gone; most are mere swamps and mud puddles. Rivers have become dry rock beds. The sad part is that the drought is not only affecting Southern California, but many surrounding areas as well. The desert is growing. 
By supporting Adam's Ale, you are not just helping us create a successful thesis project, but helping to spread the word about the importance of water conservation and advocate global change. 
I believe I speak for my cast and crew when I say thank you for your support in this project. 
Want to be a part of the project? Here's how you can help.
Currently, Adam's Ale is in the pre-production stage. It is projected that we will move into production the second week of January then on to post-production in February. All the donations gained from this campaign will provide us with the resources to do many things. For the Art Department, we need props, set decoration, and wardrobe. We need to cover general costs such as permits, insurance and meals for our cast and crew. Also, we would like to make this project special by bringing in a composer to create a unique score for the film as well as hire and singer/songwriter to write a song for the end credits of the film. Lastly, it is our goal to submit this short film to Film Festivals across the country.
Fortunately, our school has provided us with part of our budget, as well as equipment and one film location, but we are still lacking. Your donations will help us bridge the gap so we can turn this project from a student film, into a meaningful and professional work of art.
In return for your support, we have created many perks as our way of thanking you. Some of them include t-shirts bearing our Tree of Life logo, handcrafted and unique Tree of Life Pendants, movie posters signed by the cast and having your name credited in the movie as a supporter. For a complete and detailed list of perks, please check out the perks page!
If for some reason we don't reach our goal, whatever proceeds we have made will be split between providing meals to our cast and crew and production design. Whatever is left, if any, will go to post-production.
Risks & Challenges
If you know film production, you know that things ALWAYS go wrong on set. What counteracts that is the crew, organization of the producer and crew leadership, and the effectiveness of the director. Fortunately, I feel that we have a great team. I have worked with most of the crew members and I know that they put everything they have into their work. Not only that, but we have the full support of Los Angeles Film School as well as fantastic instructors there to guide us through until the end. 
The only challenges that I foresee is being able to fund the needs of the Art Department. Many things can lower the production value of a film, but one of the biggest is production design. Within this project, there are things that we have to have. Fortunately however, we have some pretty frugal and creative members of our art department team. Even if we don't completely reach our goal and are only able to buy the necessities, I know that we can figure out alternative ways to achieve what we desire for the look of the film. 
Other Ways You Can Help

The biggest way you can help us to achieve our campaign goal is to spread the word. Please like and share our social media pages. We currently have Facebook and Instagram, but will be adding Twitter and Youtube very soon. We'll be posting our progress regularly so be sure to follow us. We are extremely excited to share this project with you. 
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/adamsalemovie/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/AdamsAletheMovie/

story:
WHAT IS THE ROSEWOOD STORY?

 

'Rosewood' tells the story of Chris, a determined bass guitar student, who fails to get into a top music academy after he struggles to deal with his dad's recent tragic death. With only one opportunity left to get in, Chris decides to seek help when he stumbles upon Chester, an eccentric music teacher plucking away at the strings of a guitar, as he asks Chester to prepare him for his next audition. However, Chris struggles to learn Chester's idiosyncratic philosophy.

 

Chris - determination/tension/focus (Physicality - Inward focused, determined, burdened)

Still from pre-visualisation (Actor Kieran France playing Chris).

Annette, Chris's mother. - scared/aggressive (Physicality – Protected, isolated, fearful).

Chester Bloom - eccentric/reflection (Physicality – loose, frail). 

Still from pre-visualisation (Actor Paul Brodie playing Chester Bloom).

Music academy Judges

 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP!

 

Over the last couple of months, working towards the production of the film, the Rosewood crew have already managed to raise just over 50% of the budget, but we still need your help! 

In order to complete the film, we need to raise the rest of the budget. So we've come to Indiegogo to showcase our passionate project, and to ask for your help for a contribution towards the film. 

Your contributions will be going towards equipment hire (including 16mm film stock), securing locations, art department products & will eventually help with distribution, which will deliver our film to festivals once it is complete. These are all very important aspects of filmmaking that are essential for us to be able to make our film and to make it a success. 

Check out the chart below to see exactly where your contributions will be helping towards. 

 

OUR UNIQUE PERKS!

 

For your contributions we are offering a wide range of unique perks, including;  a copy of the film upon release, a sneak peek of the film before it's even released, concept artwork, Chester's mixtape and for those looking for something a little bigger - an executive producer credit, a sneak peek into the post-production process & a day on set with the whole cast & crew!

Concept poster artwork by Kahmun Goh

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

 

We face various challenges with this project, but none that aren't achievable with the passion and hard work the Rosewood crew have all put forth. One of the most demanding parts of the film will be the soundtrack, as it's a core emotion that will lead our characters within the film. The fact that the Rosewood sound department has decided to create the soundtrack & music score for the film themselves will be a challenge.  Over the past month they have been in the recording studio working hard to create a soundtrack that represents our character's personality, and with more time in the studio exploring and creating this representation, Rosewood will come to life. 

Sound Recordist & Guitarist - Phil Stander

Director - Jeremy Hunt & Sound Designer - Samuel Balkin

We have already secured our main location for the film, where around 50% of the film takes place (as shown below), however, there are still other locations that we are yet to find and secure. We're confident that with a little more time we can find the remaining locations that will make our film visually inspiring. 

Still from a pre-visualisation test shoot (Shot at actual location).

Another challenging aspect of the production of Rosewood is that the whole production will be shot on 16mm film. Limited by film stock, our Director and DP have been working closely together to perceive the best shots, lighting, and performance as possible. With our camera department undergoing multiple test shoots and past experience dealing with 16mm film, we are confident that 16mm will enhance Rosewood's vision.

 

MEET THE CREW

 

DIRECTOR - JEREMY HUNT              PRODUCER - DOWAN BARAK

CINEMATOGRAPHER - CAMERON DIBB        THE WRITER - RYAN WILLIAMS 

              

      GAFFER - NATHAN HATHWAY                   CAMERA OPERATOR - WILL STUTZ

 EDITOR - TOBY SHEPHERD           PRODUCTION DESIGNER - KAVYA BHARATHI

SOUND DESIGNER - SAMUEL BALKIN            SOUND RECORDIST - PHIL STANDER

SCRIPT & CONTINUITY SUPERVISOR - ALEX HYATT

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

 

We understand that not everyone is able to make a contribution, so we're only asking for you to contribute what you can afford. However, if you can't make a financial contribution, not to worry, as there are other ways in which you can help! Please spread the word and help raise awareness for our project by sharing our campaign on your social media page. Your contribution, no matter the capacity, will be greatly appreciated by all of the cast & crew!

Thank you for taking the time to read our campaign and please keep updated on our progress through our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/RosewoodShortFilm

story:
Deepest Fear is a horror film created by award winner Director Sergio Ruvalcaba and Produced as an international collaboration with artists from around the world.

Deepest Fear combines suspense, horror and emotion. It's about a Homicide Detective, Daniel who investigates the mysterious case of Laura a young girl who committed suicide. And the inexplicable last moments of her life guided by a dark game.

Suddenly the case transforms into a life treating race against one's own fears. Where there's no place to hide. And the only way out is taking your life.

"Monsters are real, and ghosts are real too. They live inside us, and sometimes, they win." Stephen king.

Deepest Fear  has a quality that is very different from most new horror films.  The project has been inspired by the work of great Asian filmmakers such as Takashi shimizu (The ring), The Pang Brothers (The eye), Masayuki Ochiai (The Shutter) and James Wan (The Conjuring).

Deepest Fear is bringing a new vision to horror films by exploring "horror" in a new way. The monster is not outside, hiding in the corner. He's inside you and there's no way to control it. Creatively, we wanted to create a film that creates tension through horror and a compelling story, rather than making people jump.

 Sergio Ruvalcaba is a writer/filmmaker who's work has been nominated all over the world. He has revived awards as best short film (2016) and best feature script (2014). In his professional career he has been involved as a Writer, Director, AD and Script supervisor in several independet films and TV projects.

Diego Sahagun is a director of photography and colorist with more than 10 years of experience in film, TV and music videos. He has worked with Intel, Bridgestone, Dell as well as several campaigns with top Mexican brands.

Eduardo Portillo is an art director co-founder of Topus Uranos: company dedicated to set design, prop's masters and production for Film and music videos. His work has been nominated in Cannes Film Festiva , MTV Millenial Awards and several places around the world.

Alsain Production Company specialized in film, video and TV. They have worked with top international brands like: Volvo · Warner Bros · Tequila Herradura · Hershey´s · Coca-Cola ·Jack Daniels · Nice de México · Kp Alazraki · Bdp Mkt · N2 Marketing.

 

There is something incredible about seeing a project completed and knowing that you had a part in making that happen! No matter the amount, your donation is INCREDIBLY appreciated and we thank you in advance for your generous contribution. Even if you can only contribute a little bit, everything helps bring us one step closer to create this amazing film.

 

Special images for you to post in Facebook and Instagram to show that you have supported "Deepest Fear"! Your name will also appear in the Thank You page of the official website.

 

Previews Perk plus a Digital Download of "Deepest Fear" and a exclusive selection of 3 wallpapers for desktop and smartphone.

 

Previews Perk plus a Exclusive Digital poster and a calendar of Digital Content: Live Periscopes of the shooting and special videos of the progress of the film.

 

Previews Perk plus a DVD of the film and exclusive video tips!

story:
Short Summary

Help us make a short film about deep regret! Our film features two LGBTQ+ characters, one of whom goes back in time to confess her love to her best friend. My hope with this film is to intrigue with questions about what our past decisions really do to form who we are, as well as provide a glimmer of LGBTQ+ representation. While filming has mostly taken place in Ithaca, New York, we will also be filming the last part in New York City, which will take a lot of resources to get there and film there.

Jessica Saideman is the Writer and Director of Time Gone By. In Time Gone By, Grace, a woman in her 40s at a dead end job and a rebellious teenage daughter, decides to go back in time to confess her feelings to her best friend. However, she finds that changing her past may not be as worth it as she thought it would be.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we need the money for:

  • Transportation - We'll be shipping a crew out to NYC for the climax of the film, so we will need money for gas
  • Krafty - We need food for our wonderful cast and crew!
  • Parking - Again we'll be in NYC and parking is expensive but we'll need somewhere to put the cars
  • Props/Production Design - A time machine and the lab that builds it needs to look cool so we need funds to get all sorts of old circuit boards and stuff
  • Location Fees - We have a great location here in Ithaca to stand in for the interior shots for NYC but we'll need to pay for cleaning fees to obtain the location

In return for funding us, for various amounts, you can get: a thank you credit, a poster, a digital copy of the film. 

Who are We?

Jessica Saideman - Writer, Director, Producer

Jessica Saideman is the writer, director, and producer of Time Gone By. She is a Junior Cinema and Photography student at Ithaca College. She wants her work to explore and represent the LGBTQ+ community, in particular women and femme identifying individuals.  She was recently in London, interning with Glasshead Productions Ltd.,  a documentary production company, and she has also worked with an independent production company in Toronto, Darius Films. This past summer she worked on the feature film The Manhattan Front as an assistant to the Wardrobe department. She has worked on many student films and also has created marketing content for the brand Malaika Apparel Co. She is very excited to see this script she has worked on for a year come to life. 

John Posca - Production Design

John has been a production designer for all four years of his college career, working on over 8 productions. He  has taken on many roles as  a designer, art director, carpenter and a painter. He has had  experience in this field for almost 10 years, including working as head carpenter for the feature film, The Manhattan Front.

Addison Rolleri and James Johnston - Associate Producers 

         

Addison Rolleri is a Junior at Ithaca College.  This past summer she worked as Props Coordinator and then 2nd Assistant Director for the professional feature film The Manhattan Front. She is also the assistant to Janice Levy as the two work on Levy’s photo-books: Over the Hump and Atomic Love Poem. James Johnston is a junior Cinema and Photography major with a minor in Integrated Market Communications at Ithaca College. He has worked on films projects throughout his college career in roles in front of and behind the camera. He also sings with Ithacappella, and creates short videos and social media content for them.

Julie Hughes - Assistant Director

Julie Hughes is a junior television-radio major at Ithaca College. Last semester, she had a blast directing the ICTV show she co-wrote called The PAs. Julie hopes to work in fiction television one day. She also really loves pugs and pickles.

Cast

Grace - Francesca Decker

Francesca is new to student films and is thoroughly enjoying the opportunity to participate in such a great project.  She started acting again about a year ago, and has since had the privilege of being in several local, community stage productions, including playing Hedy LaRue in How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, Shelby in Steel Magnolias, and most recently, Gladys in The Skin of Our Teeth.  She will be performing in April in the Ithaca Fringe Festival, and is a third semester student in the Meisner Technique under the instruction of Katie Spallone at the Actor's Workshop of Ithaca.  When she's not acting, Francesca is a family doctor in student health in Ithaca. She is having so much fun collaborating with this talented team of students, and is grateful to Jessica for giving her the chance.  She also wants to thank you for your support!

Ella - Amanda Shy

Amanda Shy is an Actor, Voice Over Artist & Producer residing in New York City.  Originally from Austin, Texas, Ms. Shy grew up studying Acting with a focus on Theater.  Upon her move to NYC, she discovered a deep passion for film work.  Amanda co-wrote, co-produced and plays one of the lead actors in the film fest honored short film, For Her.  She has also recently tied up roles on the WWI period feature, The Manhattan Front, playing historical figure Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, and in the Pittsburgh shot feature, Bystander.  As a successful Voice Over Artist, Amanda's voice can be heard in numerous commercials and promos all across the country.    

Young Grace - Maddie Stengel

Maddie is a Texan native from San Antonio, currently in her third year at Ithaca College. She's pursuing an acting major with a minor in deaf studies. Some previous work includes Ellen in Scarcity (IC), Antigone in Antigone (IC No Bucks) and Lady Capulet in Romeo and Juliet (IC Theatre Collective). Fun fact? Lin-Manuel Miranda once shared and retweeted her class project for signing Hamilton's "My Shot."

Young Ella - Carolyn Trahan

Carolyn Trahan has been working in film for a couple of years in various student films at Ithaca College, including Bar Hoppers, Anomie, Mime and Punishment, and Wake. She also has been in various Ithaca Theatre Productions such as Aliens with Extraordinary Skills and Romeo and Juliet. She is so excited to be working with this great cast and crew on this new project!

Lily - Anna D'Arcy

Anna D'Arcy is a freshman Television and Radio student at Ithaca College. In her first semester at Ithaca, she acted on ICTV's The PA's as the character Zoe. She also did a few student films, including Chimera Manor and Flowers. Anna was also in the cast of Dear Anna: A Stage Reading. She is looking forward to more acting opportunities at Ithaca and enjoys working with the cast and crew of Time Gone By.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! Tell anyone and everyone you know about this gay time travel movie.

Addison Rolleri and James Johnston - Associate Producers 
         
Addison Rolleri is a Junior at Ithaca College.  This past summer she worked as Props Coordinator and then 2nd Assistant Director for the professional feature film The Manhattan Front. She is also the assistant to Janice Levy as the two work on Levy’s photo-books: Over the Hump and Atomic Love Poem. James Johnston is a junior Cinema and Photography major with a minor in Integrated Market Communications at Ithaca College. He has worked on films projects throughout his college career in roles in front of and behind the camera. He also sings with Ithacappella, and creates short videos and social media content for them.
Julie Hughes - Assistant Director

Julie Hughes is a junior television-radio major at Ithaca College. Last semester, she had a blast directing the ICTV show she co-wrote called The PAs. Julie hopes to work in fiction television one day. She also really loves pugs and pickles.
Cast
Grace - Francesca Decker
Francesca is new to student films and is thoroughly enjoying the opportunity to participate in such a great project.  She started acting again about a year ago, and has since had the privilege of being in several local, community stage productions, including playing Hedy LaRue in How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, Shelby in Steel Magnolias, and most recently, Gladys in The Skin of Our Teeth.  She will be performing in April in the Ithaca Fringe Festival, and is a third semester student in the Meisner Technique under the instruction of Katie Spallone at the Actor's Workshop of Ithaca.  When she's not acting, Francesca is a family doctor in student health in Ithaca. She is having so much fun collaborating with this talented team of students, and is grateful to Jessica for giving her the chance.  She also wants to thank you for your support!
Ella - Amanda Shy

Amanda Shy is an Actor, Voice Over Artist & Producer residing in New York City.  Originally from Austin, Texas, Ms. Shy grew up studying Acting with a focus on Theater.  Upon her move to NYC, she discovered a deep passion for film work.  Amanda co-wrote, co-produced and plays one of the lead actors in the film fest honored short film, For Her.  She has also recently tied up roles on the WWI period feature, The Manhattan Front, playing historical figure Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, and in the Pittsburgh shot feature, Bystander.  As a successful Voice Over Artist, Amanda's voice can be heard in numerous commercials and promos all across the country.    
Young Grace - Maddie Stengel

Maddie is a Texan native from San Antonio, currently in her third year at Ithaca College. She's pursuing an acting major with a minor in deaf studies. Some previous work includes Ellen in Scarcity (IC), Antigone in Antigone (IC No Bucks) and Lady Capulet in Romeo and Juliet (IC Theatre Collective). Fun fact? Lin-Manuel Miranda once shared and retweeted her class project for signing Hamilton's "My Shot."
Young Ella - Carolyn Trahan

Carolyn Trahan has been working in film for a couple of years in various student films at Ithaca College, including Bar Hoppers, Anomie, Mime and Punishment, and Wake. She also has been in various Ithaca Theatre Productions such as Aliens with Extraordinary Skills and Romeo and Juliet. She is so excited to be working with this great cast and crew on this new project!
Lily - Anna D'Arcy

Anna D'Arcy is a freshman Television and Radio student at Ithaca College. In her first semester at Ithaca, she acted on ICTV's The PA's as the character Zoe. She also did a few student films, including Chimera Manor and Flowers. Anna was also in the cast of Dear Anna: A Stage Reading. She is looking forward to more acting opportunities at Ithaca and enjoys working with the cast and crew of Time Gone By.

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word! Tell anyone and everyone you know about this gay time travel movie.

story:
Campaign Update!!

We have a NEW Campaign to continue our efforts to get Unknown Distance The Film officially released!

Unknown Distance The Film - Round Two !!

Here is the link to our new campaign. Please give or share.

Indiegogo : https://igg.me/at/unknowndistancethefilmcontinues

www.unknowndistancethefilm.com

A few words from Director/Producer, Gordon Clark

A BIG THANK YOU!

Thank you to everyone who contributed to our campaign in Round One of Unknown Distance The Film. We didn’t reach our goal, but your contributions helped us cover a very important aspect for any film.  Music.   

Music is an essential element of the filmmaking process and is a big factor in determining success or failure. Attaining the rights to a specific song and the music composition throughout the film became a crucial and indispensable element to this story. The process is very difficult and expensive, but it is also integral to the fabric of our film. Your contributions allowed us to make this happen and we are so grateful. It looks amazing and now it sounds amazing! 

However, we still need additional funding to get the movie seen and to effect change. Sgt. Douglas Brown, the Combat Vets that participated in the film and all Veterans suffering from PTSD need your help.

Our NEW campaign, Unknown Distance The Film - Round Two, is raising funds to cover the costs of taking the film on the road. The goal is to get this documentary seen and distributed properly, so it can open some doors for our returning Veterans. The marketing strategy starts with raising awareness of our film, Unknown Distance, and expanding the profile of Sgt. Douglas Brown. Our marketing and promotion budget includes travel for Doug to attend film festivals we are participating in and media interviews, as well as film festival prerequisites such as DCPs (Digital Cinema Package) and legal fees for required documents for festival submissions and film distribution.   

Here is the link to our new campaign. Please give or share

Indiegogo : https://igg.me/at/unknowndistancethefilmroundtwo

www.unknowndistancethefilm.com

 

Unknown Distance the Film

www.unknowndistancethefilm.com

Gordon Clark, Director/Producer

Very rarely will a combat veteran reveal what is really going on in their head. Marine Sniper, Sgt. Douglas Brown was willing to step up and give a thoughtful and genuine insight into life after the battlefield. It took courage and strength to let a camera follow him around America as he spoke to other brave soldiers that are trying to fit into civilian life while struggling with the after effects of war.

I took a different approach from other documentaries when exploring the treatment of soldiers returning from combat with emotional and physical scars.

I wanted the viewer to focus on the bigger battle that soldiers with PTSD face in America. The narrative is on American soil, not on a battlefield the civilian world is unfamiliar with.

The opinions of high-ranking military that were aware of this chronic result, frustrated psychologists buried in bureaucracy and politicians that point the finger elsewhere were deliberately avoided. Instead, the attention is on the raw personal struggles of the Combat Vets in the film.

I was introduced to an amazing young man named Douglas Brown. He was a Marine Sniper for 10 years and served 5 tours in Iraq and Afghanistan. His account of the personal struggles he has endured since coming home weighed heavy on me and I felt obligated to help Doug and also make an impact on the lives of Combat Vets in America.

Douglas takes us on an eight month journey across America, engaging with fellow servicemen that were once a part of a highly trained team, with a deadly skill set that is now rendered useless.​

The story unfolds when Douglas and an Afghan interpreter, who served with him in Afghanistan, reveal the story that bonded them for life. Recalling those horrific memories triggers Doug's existing PTSD (Post Traumatic Stress Disorder) that continues to erode his personal relationships and has led to his erratic, inappropriate and self-damaging behavior.

Stories that must be told

After many broken promises from investors and frustrating attempts to raise funds for a documentary, I reached into my retirement fund and financed the production myself, with no film crew to help. Once we had made that decision, Doug and I journeyed across the United States talking to Veterans that he served with and filming the very real and raw stories they told.

I made a promise to Doug that I would finish this film. I personally have run out of funds and so much more has to be done to get their stories to the world.

The Film's Impact

This points us to the fact that more military personnel have taken their own lives after they return home than have fallen in the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Over medication and a failing support system only exasperate their efforts to restore qualify of life.

You can make a difference with these soldiers and many others like them. Your generosity means so much. Someone caring means so much to them. Seeing the response in the form of a donation helps them feel like they have completed their mission.

Our budget includes film industry standards like insurance, cameras, equipment rentals, travel, legal fees, marketing/promotion, editing, sound/color correction, music, post production, festival costs and more. 

We know not everyone can contribute, but this film is for everyone. If you are unable to financially back our documentary, Unknown Distance, we ask that you please share the campaign across all of your social networks.

Please share this  and get it out there and help the Vets that have participated, so that they feel like they have achieved something by sharing their experiences with the civilian world. Having their voices heard may be the only battle they can achieve.

One can give and receive comfort, sometimes at the same time.​

 

The Team

Douglas Brown

Marine Sniper

Born in Cheneyville, Louisiana, Douglas Brown scored number one as a rifleman out of 700 Marine recruits, paving the way to Sniper school. In a platoon of 1200, only a few will earn the rare Gold Star on their combat ribbon. Sgt. Douglas Brown earned two Gold Stars and a Purple Heart and he garnered that honour by serving 10 years and 5 tours of duty as a Marine Sniper in Iraq and Afghanistan.

“Douglas Brown is by far the best all around recruit in the platoon and stands head and shoulders above his peers with it comes to love of Corps and Country.”  - Commanding Officer, Mike Company

Sgt. Douglas Brown is the “Perfect Soldier”, but there are some things you can’t unsee. How will his ten years in combat impact him now? 

Back home on American soil, his battle continues.

 

Gordon Clark

Director, Writer, Photographer, Producer

​

Director, writer, photographer, producer Gordon Clark, based in California between 1981 and 2004, developed his career directing several global-brand television commercials and high-profile music videos. In 2004, he returned to his homeland in Africa to pursue a new path with his book, Transition Southern Africa. This sent him on a new journey, delving in and exploring the many challenges of the evolving social landscape in Africa, through film and photography.

Clark has undertaken numerous photo exhibitions, including, Who Am I, by Gordon Clark & Leon Botha, Groot Geraak (Becoming Big in gangland Cape Town) and The Outcome of Turner Adams. He wrote, directed and produced his first film, A Lucky Man, the dramatized full-length feature film covering the life story of Ernie (Lastig) Solomon, leader of the notorious 28ʼs gang in the South African Prison system. Filmed on site, using actual residents and minimal resources amid the ongoing gang wars, A Lucky Man debuted at the Cannes film Festival in 2013 and was nominated in the top five of South African films at the Indian/South African Film Awards.

Clark has the ability to go beyond creating a visually arresting film. His  unique insight stems from his desire to seek out and understand human behavior in relation to different environments. Clarkʼs latest works include Staying in the Game, a short film, written, directed and shot by Clark. It highlights the Cape flats 28’s gang and how they have adopted Nike as their uniform, as well as the highly acclaimed documentary, Behind Paradise, that he also produced, shot and promoted.

No stranger to controversy, his current documentary film, Unknown Distance, takes us on a journey across America with highly decorated Marine Sniper, Sgt. Douglas Brown. After five tours in Iraq and Afghanistan, Douglas faces an even bigger battle, reintegrating into civilian life with a skill set for killing that is now rendered useless.

 

Marleah Stout

Producer, Communications

I’m having a wonderfully fun career. I’ve been very fortunate to work in amazing jobs in a variety of fascinating industries and with many talented people. I’ve achieved multiple successes in the entertainment, publishing, fashion and art worlds. I thrive on getting air under the wings of creative projects and talented creative people. I love talking about things that I am excited about. This generates real interest and attracts it as well. 

For the last fifteen years, I’ve helped build international awareness around brands and ideas and generated global sales for many companies in Canada and the United States. I’ve launched art shows and led national media tours including Harlequin’s Romance Report, set up and appeared in articles and live and taped TV segments including CNN, ABC’s Nightline, The Hollywood Reporter, The Daily Show and The Colbert Report, as well as over 300 regional and national news programs.

story:
Who?

My name is Paul Stoichevski.  I am a documentary filmmaker currently directing and producing a documentary for Rogers TV on mental illness.  This NEW campaign is important to me because the full life story of John Hutchison needs to be told.  He is a genius inventor, known for The Hutchison Effect, gentle friendly giant and my close personal friend.  I know the many intricate details of his life that previous television producers overlooked, because they were after weird science and not the story of the man himself.  Therefore, I am the best person to tell his story.

 

You

Contributions will help us film this documentary professionally, which will increase its chances of wider distribution.  If you are going to spend a year of your life on a project, you might as well do it right.  Your contribution will also help my marketing team design a creative distribution strategy that is customized to this film’s content and target audience.  We will begin outreach to audiences and potential organizational partners before or during production.  We will also target core audiences.  The priority is to reach them effectively, and then cross over to a wider public. 

Needed

$150,000 to make this film the way I envision it.  If I do not reach my funding goal, I will apply to grants and look for private investors, which can take ages.  I prefer to deal with you fine people; at least we will all get something out of it.

So here is where the funding is going.  Note:  my crew has to travel and I always use the same trusted crew for my own documentaries.

Producers, Director, Subjects:  $18,850

Supportive Subjects, Production Staff, Set Dressing Labor, Make-up/ Hair Labor, Camera/Electrical/Grip Labor, Productions Sound Labor, Transportation Labor, Transportation, Set Dressing, Wardrobe Supplies, Make-up/Hair Supplies, Camera/Electrical/Grip Equipment, Sound Equipment, Second Unit:  $77,657.50

Editor Labor, Film Post-Production Sound, Music:  $34,600

Publicity & Promo:  $12,892.50

Insurance:  $1,500

Indiegogo Fee:  $4,500

That is as transparent as it gets. 

 

The Impact You Make

Independent filmmakers, like myself, can spend more time looking for funding than making films.  Being passionate about projects that may never happen is a difficult way to live.  When the funding is achieved for this documentary, and I know it will, it will be a joy to work on a project that I really want to work on.  There is nothing more exciting to me than to collaborate with my film crew on achieving creative uniqueness.  The completion of this film will be a way to honor the life and times of a person who well deserves it...John Hutchison.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't be too shy.  You can contribute any amount of money $$$.  We'll take it because we need it.  Get the word out about this documentary in any way you can.  You can use the Indiegogo share tools as well.

story:
Future Soldier is a full length feature Sifi film, that we've been develping over the months. We follow the journey of a rouge soldier called tyco, who gets court in a inhuman deadly experiment to create super soldiers.

The film is in current need of funds and we are looking  for inspirational individuals like your self  to make this masterpiece come to life. 

 In return for contributing to this campaign, we are offering every individual, limited edition perks and rewards.

 

So far we have secured the following;

- Feature length script 

-Experienced production teams.

- Film Locations (Shooting will start in December)  

 

         

Inspiration from films like  The terminator and Universal Soldier 

The Cast

http://www.imdb.com/title/tt6439566/

 

Costume Development

Join us on the journey

story:
The Story

One day in college, I was relaying a funny story about although no one ever assumes I’m gay, I like a ton of stereotypical gay things. Faux-hawks, roller derby, Tegan & Sara, plaid, rainbows, cats, etc... My ex-girlfriend always told me I was a “Giant Lesbian”, so my friend Sara told me to write my next script about “How I Became a Giant Lesbian”. This was the first spark of an idea.

Now that I have produced three short films and live in LA, I returned to this script for a re-write and revival. The story centers around one girl's struggle to find her place within the queer community. She wants to fit in and be visible, but that comes with a cost. She has to figure out if this new persona lives up to who she really is. This story has heart, humor, and contains some real-life experiences I've had to navigate as a femme in the lesbian scene.

Creating quality queer content is my passion and my purpose in life. I hope to make a difference for our queer community and inspire others to do the same. Visibility and representation really make a difference to gay youth. This film will make you think about what it means to be a lesbian and how to live outside stereotypical boxes.

Queer Style

I'm happy to announce that we will have wardrobe provided by Sharpe Suiting, Wild Things Clothing, Basic Butch, and Pattywack Vintage. These are queer owned and operated businesses that cater to everyone, regardless of gender expression or identity. I'm so proud to be able to feature and support queer businesses, and provide them an audience too! 

 

Budget 

All funds will go towards the creation of this film, even if we don't make the goal.

Your Donations

This will be my 4th film and my first feature. I was able to produce my other three short films with budgets of around $400 each, and relied heavily on friends and favors. Unfortunately, I'm not friends with any airlines or hotels, so this project will cost real money. Shooting in the Midwest is important for the look of the film. Being on campus in Ohio is very different than any school in California. I also want to pay homage to the region that raised me and the school where I found myself. I am in talks with professors at Ohio University to recruit film students to help bring this project to life, and will provide them with on set experience.

The more funds we are able to raise, the better quality this film will be. $20k is a very tight budget for a feature and only covers a very small crew. If we are able to raise more than that, there will be opportunities for improvement and better pay.

Risks & Challenges

Shooting a full-length feature film is quite the undertaking. It will require a lot of planning, work, hours, dedication, and passion. Good thing I have all of those! 

I have a Bachelor's Degree in Film Production and a good network of friends and film allies. I firmly believe we can make this happen. I'm a planner and an organizer, so I have plenty of time to map out everything down to the minute before our shoot this summer. I have backup ideas in place, in case something goes wrong or a location is unavailable. I also have a network of friends and filmmakers in Ohio, because I lived there for 23 years.

No Money? No Problem.

If you don't have the funds to contribute, that's alright. Help us promote and get the word out on your Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter! If you live in Ohio and have time to physically help out, contact me and we'll see what we can arrange.

My ex-girlfriend always told me I was a “Giant Lesbian”, so my friend Sara told me to write my next script about “How I Became a Giant Lesbian”. This was the first spark of an idea.
Now that I have produced three short films and live in LA, I returned to this script for a re-write and revival. The story centers around one girl's struggle to find her place within the queer community. She wants to fit in and be visible, but that comes with a cost. She has to figure out if this new persona lives up to who she really is. This story has heart, humor, and contains some real-life experiences I've had to navigate as a femme in the lesbian scene.

Creating quality queer content is my passion and my purpose in life. I hope to make a difference for our queer community and inspire others to do the same. Visibility and representation really make a difference to gay youth. This film will make you think about what it means to be a lesbian and how to live outside stereotypical boxes.
Queer Style
I'm happy to announce that we will have wardrobe provided by Sharpe Suiting, Wild Things Clothing, Basic Butch, and Pattywack Vintage. These are queer owned and operated businesses that cater to everyone, regardless of gender expression or identity. I'm so proud to be able to feature and support queer businesses, and provide them an audience too! 

 
Budget 

All funds will go towards the creation of this film, even if we don't make the goal.

Your Donations
This will be my 4th film and my first feature. I was able to produce my other three short films with budgets of around $400 each, and relied heavily on friends and favors. Unfortunately, I'm not friends with any airlines or hotels, so this project will cost real money. Shooting in the Midwest is important for the look of the film. Being on campus in Ohio is very different than any school in California. I also want to pay homage to the region that raised me and the school where I found myself. I am in talks with professors at Ohio University to recruit film students to help bring this project to life, and will provide them with on set experience.

The more funds we are able to raise, the better quality this film will be. $20k is a very tight budget for a feature and only covers a very small crew. If we are able to raise more than that, there will be opportunities for improvement and better pay.

Risks & Challenges
Shooting a full-length feature film is quite the undertaking. It will require a lot of planning, work, hours, dedication, and passion. Good thing I have all of those! 
I have a Bachelor's Degree in Film Production and a good network of friends and film allies. I firmly believe we can make this happen. I'm a planner and an organizer, so I have plenty of time to map out everything down to the minute before our shoot this summer. I have backup ideas in place, in case something goes wrong or a location is unavailable. I also have a network of friends and filmmakers in Ohio, because I lived there for 23 years.

No Money? No Problem.
If you don't have the funds to contribute, that's alright. Help us promote and get the word out on your Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter! If you live in Ohio and have time to physically help out, contact me and we'll see what we can arrange.

story:
SYLVIE

Why invest in this film?:

  • A short film surrounding the troubles facing young women who have worked in the adult industry. 
  • Contributors would be helping us make a strong film surrounding a very under discussed subject. 
  • The industry is a lot more dangerous and harming then we are lead to believe, for a media platform everyone knows about, there is still a lot of trauma these young women face. Especially with 'teen' and aggressive porn becoming more popular. 
  • 90% of most watched porn has verbal or physical abuse towards women. Clearly showing how these women are perceived and the situations they have involved themselves in.
  • Working with porn charities and women that have been in the industry we are assuring the story is realistic and representational. 

BUDGET BREAKDOWN

MEET US

        

          Writer/Director Kirsty Mclean and DoP Carmen Brussosa

Kirsty

Kirsty grew up and studied film in Edinburgh before moving to London where she studies film and TV production at University of the Arts London. Her past projects have always surrounded women issues but this is her first one covering subjects on the sex industry. In her spare time, she listens to podcasts, watches realism films and draws cartoons.

Carmen

Carmen is a Spanish aspiring cinematographer who is finishing film and TV studies in London College of Communication. She has been working in the camera and lighting department for university projects and been shooting her own personal projects at the same time. To add, she has worked on the professional film sets for commercials, music videos and feature films to encourage her existing skills.

                

           Producers Ava Cheraghi and Ruta Kuodyte

Ava

Ava was born in Tehran but raised in London, Ava inherits her blood culture into her passion for film & TV. Her enthusiasm lies in illustration and writing, and helping others bring their vision to life. She has worked on various short drama films as a production manager and producer.

Ruta

Ruta, born and raised in Lithuania, is a final year student at University of the Arts London. She has an extensive experience in management from being a project manager to producing short independent films. After moving to London, Ruta started working in events marketing company Bears&Bridges, as a projects coordinator, she also worked at Shooting Media a production company and produced a few award winning independent short films.

                

Production Designer Louise Graham and Costume Designer Beier An

Beier

Beier, born and raised in China, been passionate about the art department in film and TV for a long time, she loves to play around with the style and color in production design and brings innovative and creative ideas onboard. She has worked on multiple projects as production designer, art director and costume designer.

Louise

Louise is a current student at London College of Communication studying Live Events and Television Production. She has been trained in Fine Art for five years previous to moving into production, and since her first year at university she has been production designer for three in house short films and a few TV shows. Alongside that she started Art Assisting for a popular Channel 4 TV show.

                

Editor Shealey Wallace and Sound Designer Arianny Canepa

Shealey

Shealey has spent the last year editing a short documentary dealing with mental illnesses commissioned by the University of the Arts London, she also has taught editing short courses with the university. Before that, for the past two years Shealey have been working within the camera department as assistant camera from everything from a BBC comedy to adverts. When not hustling and bustling in film, she enjoys spying on both her idols, Mike Leigh and Ken Loach.

Arianny

Arianny, born and raised in Brazil, always had a passion for music and film. From young age she has been interested in sound recording and design, her interest led to working on a short drama films and music videos in Brazil and London where she gained a great set of skills.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need your funding for transportation, production design, catering and equipment .
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • We strongly rely on word of mouth and people being generous. The subject is something a lot of people are passionate about so the work ethic is already there!
  • If you can't afford to give us any money then please share our page and get the word out. Across all media platforms!

Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!

If you can't afford to give us any money then please share our page and get the word out. Across all media platforms!

story:
Key features:

  • Supporting young talent on and off camera!

  • Team with over 30 years combined experience!

  • Trained by BFI Academy

  • Supported by the British Film Institute and The Company Ltd

  • Short but effective story drawing parallels with modern life in an apocalyptic situation!

  • Registered Limited Production Company

 

"He is kidnapped and forced to do

the worst thing he could imagine"

 

Survived!

 

The Survived story follows Arthur, an 18 year old boy who is just about to leave home and join the army. He is celebrating his birthday with his closest friends and family and they are set to have an amazing night!

But Suddenly the power goes out and confusion sweeps the city. When Arthur goes to check the power, a loud scream pierces the air. He knows exactly who the scream belongs to.

It's an apocalypse. The stuff of horror films. Does Arthur have anything left to live for? A few months later something very unexpected happens. He is kidnapped and forced to do the worst thing he could imagine. But there's one thing on his mind. Survive.

 

The characters!

 

Arthur

Arthur, our main character, is 18 years old he is just about to join the army and start the rest of his life when an apocalypse hits! He very well equipped, strong and versatile making him perfectly adapted to the new world. However, he is also a very loving and caring character making it even more painful when he looses those close to him.

 

Jenny

Jenny, our lead actress lives at the survival camp and is a very strong young woman, however she is very mysterious at when we first meet her. However as Arthur gets to know her we find out a bit more about her and the life she had before everything happened. Arthur and Jenny become very close which spreads divisions in the camp and makes everything harder for both characters until the final scene...

 

Troy

Troy is Jenny's guardian in the new world, after he found her and her little brother early on and they got attacked, he formed a very close paternal bond to her and will protect Jenny no matter what. Troy is a very brutal character and Arthur sees him as a threat at first but when they face a common threat in this horrid world. Arthur sees the human side to Troy.

 

"One of the most convincing things

about this incredible story is how relatable it is" - Director

 

Themes:

•      Transformation (Flashbacks)

•      Sacrifice

•      Friendship

•      Love

•      Justice

•      Vengeance

 

The Survived development:

 

Before survived was even born it had to be conceived, this happened alongside 2 other projects, a short film and a feature length film. I must admit I wasn’t too keen on any of them, survived and the feature I thought would never work and the other just lacked sustenance. After development, the short film had been taken off the list, which just left survived and another project. So, we talked to the filmmakers we knew and decided that Survived was the best option! And so, it was conceived!

One of the most convincing things about this incredible story is how relatable it is. Obviously not the zombie apocalypse part but the young people and their stories. The story has a huge focus on the characters and their relationships which have become more and more important to me personally. I think one of the most amazing things about the story is how it shows that we are so engrossed in the internet and everything else that sometimes it can take a huge disaster to bring people together!

Myself and Jackson (Writer) decided to embark on our own and the company’s biggest project yet. Jackson began writing it while I started contacting filmmakers to seek advice and help. Then, with 5 episodes scripted we both took part in a British Film Institute course where we met our core crew!

Luckily everyone who we asked loved the idea and said they would help. So, we had a crew, a script and producer. Now we had to find cast! This was a fairly simple process as we only needed to film 5 scenes. The reason for this is after talking with the crew we decided it would be more beneficial and less risky to film the simple bits and edit a trailer. This made finding a cast easier as they were simple scenes and we did not need to do any auditions (For the final project we will be).

And finally, in late 2016, early 2017 we started filming our 5 scenes, all days went well and you can find one of the trailers on this page now!

 

"[I want survived to] help young people whether they be

filmmakers, actors or musicians to reach their goal"  - Director

 

The plan:

Survived is a very ambitious project. It will require a lot of effort and planning to pull off. However, with your contribution, we can make an amazing short series.

We value every contribution to our project and that is why we will try to give every donor a personalized response because we do value it! I have included the rough plan for our production schedule here:

•      Develop script (Summer 2017)

•      Location search (Late 2017)

•      Auditions (Early/Mid 2018)

•      Secure locations

•      2-3 Week filming process with 2 units (Summer 2018)

•      Editing

•      Premiere & Release (October-November 2018)

The whole team will do our best to stick to this schedule and we will of course keep you up to date on the whole production, if you donate a bit more you can even get to see some behind the scenes!

Here is some additional information you might like to know:

The team:

•      William – Director

•      Jagpreet – Producer

•      Jackson – Writer

•      Luke Furmage – Producer

•      5 Executive producers

•      Managing team (10)

•      Production and Post production crew (35)

Advantages to donating:

•      Supporting young talent on/off screen

•      Cast & Crew from all over the UK

•      Experienced crew (BFI, NFTS)

•      Large production

•      Carefully selected cast/crew both experienced and inexperienced

•      Diverse cast and crew to support young people from all backgrounds

•      Proof of concept

•      Already raised over £250 to begin production and to film trailer

•      Fresh perspective on genre

•      Help prove low budget films can look amazing!

•      Registered Production Company                        (Hillpeak Productions Limited)

 

"[I wanted to] focus more on the human survival

rather than the zombies and action" - Writer

 

The deal:

We’re aiming to raise £5,000 from this campaign, our primary goal is to establish an audience and begin production. We have already had a grant of £300 as well as raising almost £300 to begin our project. You can find more details about the finance below.

Our company has a huge advantage in that we comprise of indie filmmakers and many young people. This allows us to budget very efficiently as we are used to working with very small budgets. For example, we will release 5 different trailers over the next few months that have all been made on a budget of £250 for everything, from equipment to props and costumes.

The majority of the £5,000 raised from this initial campaign will go towards marketing as well as the art department and catering. The whole survived project has 4 marketing campaigns each with increasing budget. This fundraiser is being launched alongside marketing 1. Most likely, around £1000-£2000 will go towards the other marketing campaigns with focus on the later stages of development.

During pre-production, our company needs financial resources to allow us to get off with to good start. Here is a short breakdown of our preproduction costs:

·        Admin costs (printing scripts, meeting places, transport) -- £200

·        Actors (Audition venue for 2 days, transport, call out adverts, printing) -- £500

·        Script management (Rewriting, editing, finalizing, research) -- £100

·        Leaflets and outreach -- £100

 

 

The Finance:

The exact production costs for Survived are as follows!

·        Props/costumes and makeup - £2000

·        Locations - £1000

·        Cast/Crew/Exec - £1000

·        Equipment - £2000

The figures above are however, for a minimum budget of £5000 we are hoping to raise further funds with future stunts, crowdfunders, investors and grants our final budget being hopefully around £10,000 to £15,000. These figures will vary and in interest of full disclosure we will keep everyone 100% up to date with figures.

 

Meet the team behind Survived on the website!

 

 

"It has really taught me a lot about

producing and filmmaking in general!"  - Producer

 

The big idea:

Hillpeak Productions Limited, based in Birmingham is a small production company with three founding members, myself William, Jackson and Jagpreet. You can check out our website. Survived will be our biggest project to date, however with such an experienced crew and an amazing script the goals for the project are easily achievable.

The story follows Arthur (our main character) in this post-apocalyptic world. After a disaster at the start of a new life, he is forced to deal with loosing everyone close to him and has to survive on his own for months. After the same routine day after day, Arthur gets picked up by the only living people he’s seen in weeks. He has to take the seemingly kind offer of a safe place to live and survive… But what are the costs?

The planned release of this series is late in 2018, and we’ve already filmed some test shots and scenes for your enjoyment and you can stay tuned to the campaign to catch our periodic trailers.

“As the director of Survived I wanted to do something different to what I know I would have done a long time ago. I remember growing up and thinking how cool it would be to make an action movie with lots of guns and special effects. While I still think, this might be something to embark on in the future, as an indie filmmaker at my age with my experience I would much rather focus on a short and sweet, uncomplicated story.

When my writer (and best friend) came to me with this idea I immediately thought… no way am I making that movie it’s going to end up under budgeted and it’ll look unprofessional and silly. But being the kind person I am I said, go away, script it and keep it simple.

When he brought it back to me I was astounded…? I knew he was on the verge of an amazing story and provided we could keep it simple and focus on the characters we could make it! Sadly, half way through pre-production it hit me (with a nudge from my producer) that we weren’t going to be able to make that series, at least not yet…

UNTIL NOW! So, I look forward to what this project holds and I really hope we can raise the budget to make an amazing film!

 

Facebook

Instagram: survived_series & hillpeak_productions

YouTube

 

"as an indie filmmaker at my

age with my experience I would much rather

focus on a short and sweet, uncomplicated story."  - Director

 

Our story:

The story… Or should I say stories! There’s so many working parts and amazing people involved in this project that it would be impossible to just tell one story. So, let’s start off with the individual stories of our writer, director and producer.

The Director – William Terry-Wright

            The first thing that really ignited my passion for filmmaking was a short summer course I took part in when I was about 11. I’d been making YouTube videos for a long time by then but this course took my filmmaking up by a notch or two! We got to use very professional equipment and it was more or less the spark that I needed, from there I started improving my video quality, I started using an SD video camera and scripting my shorts. I read lots of books on filmmaking, I read blogs, magazines, articles, youtube videos, anything I could get my hands on to learn more about filmmaking.

My best friend at the time and now Hillpeak colleague, Jackson was also making videos for Youtube so we started to partner up, scripting and storyboarding for each other. Sadly, this did not last and school commitments took over our lives. Until 2015 when we both sat down and decided we would start making videos, but this time they would be well scripted and more professional.

Admittedly our early tries were not very successful but we soon got the hang of it and started making more and more videos and started doing film reviews. The shorts we were making were not masterpieces by any means however they each had their strengths. Some were very cinematic, some had lots of action, some were stupid comedy sketches (Yes I still laugh at them to this day) and others were just silly videos we made because we were bored.

It was soon after this that Hillpeak Productions was born. We knew we had to start upping our budgets from double figures and we wanted them to look even more professional. It gave us a platform to pitch with and somewhere to put our best videos.

Then, in early 2016, Survived was born.

We decided we would both embark on our biggest project to date and we began bouncing ideas back and forth. After some debating we pitched two or three to some local filmmakers. Survived happened to be the most achievable so we began storyboarding and scripting. See the survived story for more.

The Writer – Jackson Clifford.

Me and William decided we would embark on our biggest project yet and I started to write the series. Initially it was going to be a short film, however after some consideration we decided to turn it into a 5 part series. This allowed us to pack a bit more in but also leave cliff hangers and let the audience become more invested.

After a few edits we had a great script and we pitched it to a group of young people who were into filmmaking and the rest is history! If we raise the goal then I would starrt to rewrite a bit more to extend and shorten parts to get it as good as possible and do some character building!

 

The Producer – Jagpreet Jhamat

I attended the BFI academy in Birmingham and that's where I met Jackson and Will who told me about Survived. After the academy I was asked to produce it as that is what I ultimately want to get involved in!

It's been very interesting taking part in Survived so far, I've met some amazing actors and actresses and it has really tought me a lot about producing and filmmaking in general!

I hope that we raise a full budget because I really want to see some of these young cast and crew flourish and I also think it is a great story to tell and I would love to be on the red carpet as well! Haha!

 

The Hillpeak Story

Hillpeak Productions Limited is an incorporated company (www.hillpeakproductions.co.uk) conceived by William Terry-Wright and directed by Jackson and Jagpreet. When the name Hillpeak Productions was first born, we had no idea it would grow so big.

It started off as a small youtube channel and a logo that we’d put on our videos. That’s what it was after months of debating and planning. That is until mid-2016 when Jackson and William started making some more professional films. They then met Jag and saw her excellent potential and then, early 2017 Hillpeak Productions was turned into Hillpeak Productions Limited, registered and ready to trade. After just 4 months, the company had gone from just a youtube channel to having a huge, professional website; 5 portfolio videos; 3 directors; 6 employees and a limited company. So naturally our next step is to embark on what we hope will make our company more well known in the industry.

Survived is mostly funded and commissioned by Hillpeak Productions Limited and its partner Riverside films and will hopefully be the start of an amazing business!

 

"I hope that we raise a full budget because I really want to see some of these young cast and crew flourish and I also think it is a great story to tell and I would love to be on the red carpet as well! Haha!"  - Producer

 

Your help?

We’d love to hear from you, send us an email at survived@hillpeakproductions.co.uk and let us know what we did well, what could we do better? Also, we’d love to know if you donated and why! Even if you didn’t donate or want to find out more then we’d love to help!

Either way, please check us out on social media we’re on facebook, instagram, twitter and snapchat! Also, share the campaign with your zombie loving friends and tell them how cool we are!

 

Best wishes,

The Hillpeak Team
