story:
What is Monarch About?

STORY: The film is set in the 90s in a small, sleepy town. It centers around Agnes, a young woman in her 20s who waits on tables at the local diner. When she is not caring for her prescription addicted mother, she is constantly studying serial killer cases and is enthralled by them. After a small string of murders that happen in her community, she seeks out after the media sensationalized "Monarch Murderer". After stumbling upon “Monarch” in the middle of a murdering his latest victim in the woods, Agnes is caught and becomes the next victim in line. Locked in his basement, she must use all of her skills to break free and ultimately decide whether to comply with his demands or resist.

BACKGROUND: We are introduced to Agnes as an intelligent individual and thinks highly of her abilities. Besides having to deal with her abusive prescription addicted mother, Agnes spends her time investigating the recent string of murders. Her house is messy, reeks of cigarettes, and is littered with the memories of  abandonment from her family. She is the opposite of her living situation. The black sheep in her family, if not, her town. From her very neat room, you can tell she is calculated, observant, and each item is placed with precision and purpose. Her obsession with tracking down the serial killer has consumed her entirely.

Agnes is a film that feels like a thriller, bleeds like horror and deals with the complexities of a teenage girl becoming a woman like an indie film. It is set in the 90s and is inspired by the raw cult classic films of that era. Agnes represents the powerful female characters that people still adore today. Characters such as Clarice Starling in Silence of The Lambs, Karen Hill in Goodfellas and Mathilda in The Professional. Women who were presented with difficult choices and had to own their power and become stronger than their circumstances.

Agnes is the hero of her own story. She creates it, writes it and ends it in her thrilling fashion. The film is a love letter to women who feel different, women who feel human and messy and don’t always make the right choices.

VISUAL TONE AND STYLE: The visual tone and style will be dark and horror based. Similar to the style of “It Follows”, that sleepy small town stillness that leaves a pit in your stomach. Visually it will beautiful and cinematic, creatively using color to express the characters moods and where the story is headed. It will feel fast paced in the thrill as we feel Agnes’ anxiety.  

Since Agnes is set in the 90s, we will stay true to the early 90s era, using technology from that time, CD players and old TV sets.

The soundtrack should feel like an 80s horror film with a mix of classic rock from the 70s. The score should be cinematic and original.

 

CHARACTERS:

AGNES (20s): An outcasted young woman with a curious, intellectual mind. She’s a lovable tomboy and misfit who gets caught up when her obsessions with true crime manifests in the real world. A young Winona Ryder or Natalie Portman. A cunning yet antisocial young woman who lives in her own world.

During the start of the film we feel her feel, insecurities and helplessness but as the film flips and she owns her power we see the creation of a completely new character. By the end of the film we are mesmerized by her, her transformation is extraordinary and she becomes a cult hero.

THE MONARCH MURDERER (MID 40s): Our killer is physically intimidating, his size and strength is enough to allow Agnes to feel weak. A highly skilled huntsman, active outdoorsman, and overall a man’s man. He can also make a killer cocktail.

Mentally he’s going through a midlife crisis. He doesn’t feel like himself, he’s emotional and touchy, he smokes too many cigarettes, and feels the need to carry his legacy on yet he doesn’t have any children. At times he’s lovable and weirdly charming, feeling and grooving to old records he plays. His human nature makes him all the more terrifying. We ask ourselves how can we love a man that’s so horrible. There seems to be no method to his madness and he often spirals off like the joker or Jack Nicholson in The Shining. We fear his unpredictability and the fact that he’s a man with a terribly sick and twisted mind.



STRATEGY: ‘Monarch’ will be first shot as a 10-15 minute low budget short film and submitted to all major film festivals. The short will be used to promote the possibility of a feature film or television series furthering the character development and story.

Why This Film Is Important

As a filmmaker my ultimate goal is to make audiences think differently, it's in my nature to shake things up. With "Monarch" we see a classic tale of a deranged serial killer and his victim but the twists and turns bring us back to the complexity of human nature.  

Monarch is important because we believe the world is ready for new stories about women. With this film we are able to explore and dig deeper into the psychology of how women have been written onscreen. With "Monarch" we bring you a film that's both beautiful to look at as well as to think about and discuss. 

In helping us make this film you are giving  female filmmakers a platform to rewrite how women are viewed on screen. But more importantly you are giving women a chance to tell a story from our perspective and this changes everything. 

What We Need 

  • Location Fees: The story takes place in a creepy cabin.
  • Camera Rental: We plan to shoot on a high end camera as the film deserves to look as beautiful as we imagine it to be. 
  • Crafty: We've got to feed our hardworking crew!
  • Post-production: We plan to have the film professionally edited, sound mixed, scored, etc.
  • Festival submission fees: Sundance here we come!
  • Marketing costs: Poster art, website, trailer, etc

The Impact

"As a filmmaker, I truly believe in shaking it up and I feel Monarch does just that. My rebellious nature wants to shock audiences, but my sweet side wants you to learn something or leave changed for the better. I'm in love with this story, the way it flowed out of me was so natural. I knew it was a film that needed to be seen. The characters are so rich, my producer Jessica and I have already been discussing them as if they we're people we both knew. It's rare to get a crew together that's as passionate as ours and I know the final product will be magical. I know this story will resonate with people, it will be a classic and I'm already writing a pilot script in case Netflix options a series out of this. I believe in MONARCH!"

-Crystal Friedman (Writer/Producer/Director)

Our Crew

Crystal Friedman (Writer/Producer/Director): 

Crystal Friedman is a self-taught filmmaker who does it all. She's dabbled in every possible aspect of filmmaking for the past 10 years and has taught herself everything from pre-production through to post-production. As a filmmaker and artist her goal and passion is to shift the audiences' thinking. She started out making comedic pieces with her friends which strangely turned into darker psychological horror/thriller and sci-fi think pieces. She believes that a good film has the power to change the world, bring people together and start a conversation.

Crystal's debut short 'Virgin Virgin' screened at The Saratoga International Film Festival (2016) and has over 82,000+ views on YouTube. Her second short 'We Are Not Lovers' premiered at the HollyShorts Film Festival (2017) and screened at DAMN! Film Series late October (2017) in NYC. The film also won "Best Film" at DAMN! FILM SERIES and was awards funding for her next project. "We Are Not Lovers" is currently being distributed by Hewes Pictures. You can find these films streaming on Amazon Prime.

Crystal has wrapped post-production on two other sci-fi, horror, thriller shorts she shot late last year. 'River' a short about a time traveling mad man and 'Always Forever' which is about a girl with an untrustworthy robot boyfriend. Both films are currently being submitted to film festivals around the US. 

She is currently in pre-production on the short film 'Monarch'.

OFFICIAL SITE

INSTAGRAM

Jessica Horrigan (Producer): 

Jessica Horrigan is a Mexican-American Los Angeles based film producer, originally from Scottsdale, Arizona. She has over 10 years of experience with features, short films, documentaries, commercials, and music videos. Her latest producing work, I’ll Have a Salad, is a short film about the pressures of dating in an anxious Millennial world.

Jessica currently works at CESD Talent Agency, assisting the Theatrical and Voice Over departments where she handles actors bookings on various high profile TV and film projects. Such projects that she has been involved with are The Society (Netflix), The Walking Dead (AMC), Young Sheldon (CBS), and booking VO talent for top brands such as Nike, Skittles, McDonalds, and more.

Jessica's passion is telling real stories about real people that revolve around trials and triumphs.  She spends her free time being active within the producing community by attending producing related events such as the Producer’s Guild of America’s Producing Conference. She also takes the time to give back to the community and volunteer at the non-profit, Made in Her Image, an organization that is based towards empowering young girls of color in film, media and more.

Jessica spends her free time traveling, reading, and spending countless hours at the beach. She stays active within the producing community by attending producing related events such as the Producer’s Guild of America’s annual Producing Conference. She also takes the time to give back to the community and volunteer at the non-profit, Made in Her Image, an organization that is based towards empowering girls of color in film, media and more.

OFFICIAL SITE

INSTAGRAM

 

Maraya Gibson (Producer)

Born in Chicago, raised in So Cal - Maraya was bitten by the film bug early on and decided to pursue a career in the film industry. After graduating with a Cinema degree from San Francisco State, Maraya started an Internship at Tiny Hero - where she helped edit commercials and trailers for ABC, Disney, Marvel, Showtime and Lionsgate. Thereafter, she scored another Internship turned Executive Assistant job at Film Independent - where she worked the LA Film Festivals and Spirit Awards. This led to a Producer's Assistant job - and subsequently Maraya began working on other short films as a Production Coordinator, 2nd AD and eventually as a  Producer. Along with producing short films - Maraya works in Original Programming at Starz supporting shows such as VIDA, Outlander, and BMF. Overall - she's interested in grounded, stylish, fun and moving films with stellar writing. 

 

Michael Greenwood (Director of Photography):

Michael Greenwood is a Los Angeles cinematographer. His passion with visual storytelling has fueled his obsession with the craft for over ten years. He is always looking to collaborate with new clients and strengthen his relationships with the community; mainly working on narrative and commercial projects.

OFFICIAL SITE

INSTAGRAM

Risks & Challenges

Independent filmmaking is a difficult task, when it works it's magical and when it doesn't we pray our crew is strong enough to take the hits. Luckily, our crew is extremely professional and we've gone on to have our films play at great festivals like HollyShorts in Los Angeles and even winning "Best Film" at DAMN! Film Series in New York City. Our crew is extremely passionate about taking our films to the next level and we will do all in our power to make sure this film is seen far and wide. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, we would love it if you could:

Spread the word to your friends and family!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign around!

Thank you!

'River' a short about a time traveling mad man and 'Always Forever' which is about a girl with an untrustworthy robot boyfriend. Both films are currently being submitted to film festivals around the US. 
She is currently in pre-production on the short film 'Monarch'.
OFFICIAL SITE
INSTAGRAM

Jessica Horrigan (Producer): 
Jessica Horrigan is a Mexican-American Los Angeles based film producer, originally from Scottsdale, Arizona. She has over 10 years of experience with features, short films, documentaries, commercials, and music videos. Her latest producing work, I’ll Have a Salad, is a short film about the pressures of dating in an anxious Millennial world.
Jessica currently works at CESD Talent Agency, assisting the Theatrical and Voice Over departments where she handles actors bookings on various high profile TV and film projects. Such projects that she has been involved with are The Society (Netflix), The Walking Dead (AMC), Young Sheldon (CBS), and booking VO talent for top brands such as Nike, Skittles, McDonalds, and more.
Jessica's passion is telling real stories about real people that revolve around trials and triumphs.  She spends her free time being active within the producing community by attending producing related events such as the Producer’s Guild of America’s Producing Conference. She also takes the time to give back to the community and volunteer at the non-profit, Made in Her Image, an organization that is based towards empowering young girls of color in film, media and more.
Jessica spends her free time traveling, reading, and spending countless hours at the beach. She stays active within the producing community by attending producing related events such as the Producer’s Guild of America’s annual Producing Conference. She also takes the time to give back to the community and volunteer at the non-profit, Made in Her Image, an organization that is based towards empowering girls of color in film, media and more.
OFFICIAL SITE
INSTAGRAM
 
Maraya Gibson (Producer)
Born in Chicago, raised in So Cal - Maraya was bitten by the film bug early on and decided to pursue a career in the film industry. After graduating with a Cinema degree from San Francisco State, Maraya started an Internship at Tiny Hero - where she helped edit commercials and trailers for ABC, Disney, Marvel, Showtime and Lionsgate. Thereafter, she scored another Internship turned Executive Assistant job at Film Independent - where she worked the LA Film Festivals and Spirit Awards. This led to a Producer's Assistant job - and subsequently Maraya began working on other short films as a Production Coordinator, 2nd AD and eventually as a  Producer. Along with producing short films - Maraya works in Original Programming at Starz supporting shows such as VIDA, Outlander, and BMF. Overall - she's interested in grounded, stylish, fun and moving films with stellar writing. 
 

Michael Greenwood (Director of Photography):
Michael Greenwood is a Los Angeles cinematographer. His passion with visual storytelling has fueled his obsession with the craft for over ten years. He is always looking to collaborate with new clients and strengthen his relationships with the community; mainly working on narrative and commercial projects.
OFFICIAL SITE
INSTAGRAM

Risks & Challenges

Independent filmmaking is a difficult task, when it works it's magical and when it doesn't we pray our crew is strong enough to take the hits. Luckily, our crew is extremely professional and we've gone on to have our films play at great festivals like HollyShorts in Los Angeles and even winning "Best Film" at DAMN! Film Series in New York City. Our crew is extremely passionate about taking our films to the next level and we will do all in our power to make sure this film is seen far and wide. 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially, we would love it if you could:
Spread the word to your friends and family!
Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign around!
Thank you!

story:
Welcome to those who have found this page, interested in independent film-making, or just looking for a darkly humorous, very awkward but honest story that examines the pitfalls of poor communication. This is ‘Get In, Get Done, Get Out’. 

What is the story about?

‘Get In, Get Done, Get Out’ is a short film that follows Peta and Elijah, as they prepare to do their first mysterious ‘job’. Peta (Cláudia Saavedra) is the no-nonsense realist pulled into this by the eternally optimistic, somewhat naive Elijah (Phil Greenoak), so their relationship is examined as well. We believe this dynamic will also resonate with the viewer.

The writer is Lanre Ajayi (www.lanrefiction.com), who has scripted Judgement (filmed in conjunction with The Drama Centre, London) and written the upcoming short, Three Knocks, as well as other shorts in development.

”I wrote this script because I wanted to take a light-hearted look at what happens when we don’t listen or talk to each other. It’s affecting us socially, politically and personally. I want us to avoid further situations where we stampede into trouble of disaster because we didn’t listen and we didn’t engage, and this is a short representation of that”

The film will be directed by Bálint Molnár (www.balintmolnar.com), who’s body of work as includes Spiced Up, Facing Facts, Lack Of Respect and the forthcoming Albert Bridge.

What do we need (and why)?

To make the film of the quality that you deserve, we require the nominal amount of £1500.

The basics are below, an any extras (such as travel expenses) are being financed personally. Please see the chart below detailing how the amount has been broken down:

 

The amount has factored Actor and Crew wages, as well as professional equipment and transporting it around London over several days.

There are items of clothing and props that are required for hire, but those have been identified and we are able to keep those costs as low as we can without compromising quality.

And finally, we intend to market the film and submit it to festivals, as and where appropriate.

What’s in it for you?

For those able to contribute, we will deliver items such as copies of posters, scripts and on set photos, as well as a digital copy of the film when it is available. Social media recognition and your name in the credits are also redeemable. If you can pledge more, you can visit the set and you will be credited as an Executive Producer and may even be an extra in the film.

As time goes on, we will be engaging with pledgers, giving you the opportunity to win items from set and other related items.

If you are unable to pledge?

Not to worry and no offence taken! We thank you for taking time to visit us, and we would be most grateful if you could spread the word and share the campaign via your various social media platforms. Your support is most appreciated.

story:
Short Summary

Johnny Weichel and Connor Smith have been in talks about collaborating since 2018 and finally have something to share:

  • A little about Johnny (Co-Director/DP) - A Floridian by birth, Johnny now calls Chicago home. He is a filmmaker by trade and has been producing videos for over five years. "Phosphorescence" will be his 10th short film!
  • A little about Connor (Co-Director/Producer) - An Arkansas native, Connor is taking his visual anthropology degree and applying it to his art. Spending time in acting, improv and writing communities, he's excited to bring his diverse background to this very humanistic story.
  • With Johnny's experience in film production and Connor's acting knowledge, they are primed and ready to rock on this project!

What We Need & What You Get

Down to the nitty-gritty:

  • Plain and simple, our goal is to raise $5,000 by mid-May at the earliest and end of June at the latest. Your contribution to the project will help cover crew costs, gear rental, crafty, post-production (editor, colorist, sound mixing), and festival submission fees.
  • Let's get specific:

  • Our perks include a credit at the end of the film, updates on the progress of the project, a chance to see early cuts of the film, and an invitation to a private screening with cast and crew.
  • If we don't reach our goal of $5,000, we will adjust our budget accordingly and make appropriate sacrifices pertaining to production and post-production.

The Impact

You have a chance to help our entire team realize a dream:

  • The dream of the film - we want to share this honest look into what it means to lose someone; to lose connection and the feeling of abandonment that comes with loss.
  • The dream of the team - Connor and Johnny are not the only ones with something to gain; our team is comprised of hard-working individuals who want to make this work a profession. This is one more step toward that goal.
  • Your participation in this campaign means getting this story out to the world and potentially impacting someone's life.

Risks & Challenges

There has never been a production that has run perfectly, but with enough money we can guarantee that we have a team of professionals backing our every move.

Other Ways You Can Help

Chances are you're another artist friend who barely has enough money to help realize your own dreams; we get it! Here are some other ways to help:

  • Help us get the word out! Share this campaign anywhere and everywhere. Just because you're not in Illinois, the USA, North America, or planet Earth doesn't mean you can't help.
  • Send us encouragement via our film's e-mail address - phosphfilm@gmail.com.

 

Thanks for your support!

-The Phosphorescence Team

story:
In today's society, school shootings have become a normality, an item of casualty. We live in a world filled with disguised hatred for one another's culture. Why is this?

Felicity Fungus' Annual Maternity Tea Party Society is a 20 minute narrative short film with the aim to tackle the theme of oppression against individuality/creativity and how this may often lead to extremist behaviour, also highlighting the problems with the current education system. Once every nine months, three women, whom are in their final month of pregnancy, get together to have a tea party. Having attended school together, the three women reflect on their childhood, re-enacting scenes of past trauma in a masochistic manner. Spending the day performing strange activities, the women happen to give birth all together and prepare a three course dinner meal out of questionable and grotesque ingredients. 

Having written this script, I managed to find a way to express my personal angst against the current situation of the educational system. From my own experience and having spoken the subject matter through with various people, I have realised that the educational system has its significant flaws. It is rigid, unsupportive and deludes itself. Schools have built for themselves an environment which corners the pupil, where teachers induce fear and prudence and take away all the courage to create something unique and challenge oneself, which results to conformity and lack of individuality. Schools lack the environment in which one can develop and build their own identity as well as taking away the excitement that learning should promote.

I wish to raise awareness for this subject, as I think many major problems of today's world can be traced back to the development stage of its individuals, education playing a key role to the development of a healthy society. The film underlines the significance of the education of arts and how arts is an easy way to introduce people to the worlds different cultures, essentially creating topics of of conversation and leading to healthy communication.

SET DESIGN FOR FILM:

SET DESIGN: The film is set in the modern day, but follows three characters who are opposed to the conventions of the mundanity of modern day society. In their desperate attempt to distance themselves from the banal modern day society, the characters have surrounded themselves in a heavily designed attic space, in which Felicity inhabits. To convey the characters' anti-mainstream behaviours, it is essential for the set to also reflect and compliment their unconventional aesthetics. To convey this, the set will be cluttered in unusually designed props and will have a highly saturated and warm colour palette, with browns, reds and greens, taking inspiration from from the sets within Peter Greenaway and Jean Pierre Jeunet/Marc Caro films.

Example of a previous set that I designed & built that has a similar aesthetic to the set in the film:

CINEMATOGRAPHY / FILM AESTHETIC: The film will be shot on the Arri Alexa and will be using a Set of Vintage Cooke Lenses, which alongside the Set Design, will convey the unconventional behaviours of the characters. The shots will have little movement, being on a Tripod throughout the majority of the film, although there will be a few shots using tracks and a Dolly. The film will have a warm colour palette, of browns and reds, with a blue skyline in contrast. Below is a mood board of the general aesthetic of the film.

COSTUME: The three women have a very distinctive and anti-fashion, yet avant-garde way in which they dress themselves, the amalgamation of different styles and sub-cultures, inspiration from contemporary designers such as Dilara Findikoglu and inspiration also from from Tudor to 70s Punk, Glam rock to absurd vintage 18/1900s costume.

FINIAN CLARKE (Director/Writer/Set Designer) - Since emerging from the womb, I have sought to challenge the meaning of identity and the mainstream culture of today, through my work as an Artist, Set Designer and Filmmaker. My work takes inspiration from Peter Greenaway, Todd Solondz, Jan Svankmajer and Surrealist cinema, which one can see through my use of a strong colour palette and quirky visual style and themes.

SORIN BALUTA (Producer) - Sorin is a London based producer. He has produced various narrative projects both inside and outside the boundaries of London. His enthusiasm manifests especially for projects which extend beyond normality, plots and stories with a “higher-than-reality” quality, sets and locations that can evoke a unique world, vision and imagination. He has built in time a strong collaboration history with the director Finian through numerous other film productions.

LIVAN GARCIA-DUQUESNE (Producer) - Livan is a filmmaker and musician based in London who specialises in producing, directing and scoring and has produced a variety of different projects in London with directors from Europe. With enthusiasm for European and Asian cinema, his extensive knowledge will be critical in the development of the creative decisions of the project, alongside the organisation.

FABIO MOTA (Cinematographer) - Having recently graduated his masters in Cinematography at the Nation Film and Television School, Fabio's high attention to detail within both the Camera and Art Department is crucial for the project. His creative suggestions on set and way in which he collaborates with Finian as a Production Designer, is essential to aestheticise the film.

WENZHE LI (Art Asst) - WenZhe is a multi-disciplinary artist who works in different media of performance, photography and art direction. Having collaborated in the art department alongside Finian many times before, she will be crucial in the organisation of the art department.

JUSTIN KNIGHT (Asst) - When not working on his clothing brand and music, Justin is a filmmaker, interested in subversive afro-futurism, surrealism and science fiction films. With a positive way of thinking and sense of humour, Justin creates a great on-set atmosphere.

DESCRIPTIONS FROM NARRATOR DIALOGUE IN SCRIPT:

MISS FELICITY FUNGUS -  Miss Felicity Fungus, an aspiring author still in her jejunity, whose aptitude and intellect hast not been recognised, passes the hours pressing pen to paper, etching provocative sonnets, hiding herself within words, ideas of which come from experiences in her brief-lived but eventful wait for purgatory. To support her writing aspirations, Felicity makes her dime spending her Saturday nights spreading her legs in a room above a Chinese restaurant to greasy-haired buisnessmen, whose release of sweat from assault with a friendly weapon, smells like the pungeant chow mein they have eaten on the floor below. Her way of life has caused her to suffer from chronical urinary infection, which causes her a great deal of pain, resulting in her having regular check-ups with a man named Dr Samuel Owen Searchy. Spending her life in solitude, unless in the company of Fonula or Sybilla, Felicity passes her hours critiquing the country’s craving and parasitic obsessions to conformity.

MISS FONULA DIXON-PADGETT - As a young bairn, Miss Fonula Dixon-Padgett was born with dancing blood cells and had music running through her veins. Having recognised her talents from an early age, her deceased uncle had left money on his will for Fonula to be sent to a private tutor in London away from her parents, whose pickled brains believed they had two identical twin daughters, due to their poor eyesight from spending their days guzzling pots of melted down shoe polish to feed their intoxicated minds. Whilst at her tutor, Fonula was taught the harpsichord, but had three of her fingers broken when her tutor, Mr Adley, slammed down the case on her hands. She never played again... After a change of profession, Miss Fonula yields her crowns, scrubbing underneath the large folds of skin for a senile woman named Mrs Trudy Johnson, whose appetite has certainly beaten anorexia. Fonula has experienced three miscarriages of seven pregnancies, causing her severe phobia of menopause, for which she is often teased by her present companions. She is also missing her left eyebrow, which flares up red when she is anxious or agitated.

MISS SYBILLA PHLEGM - Their buckle to the belt, Miss Sybilla Phlegm, although coy on the outside, hides her abyss of complexion through the placement of pigment on canvas. Sybilla was born with trembling fingers and suffered from uncontrollable ticks and at 18 months, she had been written off as a failure. However, Sybilla spent her every day of childhood as if it were her last, applying daubs of impasto paint to paper, as it had been noticed her ticks would suddenly come to a pause when equipped with a paintbrush. Being the daughter of an architect and playwright, creativity filled the family’s oxygen-depleted blood cells, and inspiration by simply living, filled the ventricles in their every breath. Sybilla’s painting ambitions were met with her parents optimism and support, however arguments would often break when they would take her teachers’ word as gospel, when informed that Sybilla was a low-achieving student. As a whole, the family had unlocked the keyhole to happiness, however, their happiness and cackling laughter would turn into a crackle of embers, when they were caught inside their house, ablaze, Sybilla, escaping the fumes alone, bringing only a permanent growth on her lung caused by the toxic smog, which accounts to her regular coughing fits. Sybilla now lines her pockets pouring slop onto young school children’s dinner plates, stood alongside trivial half-witted women who reek of pork fat, their excess of flaky skin on their hands making its way as a garnish on the top of the dishes.

NARRATORS (NOT FROM SCRIPT) - The two Narrators will be played by seven year old boys, whose head's are trapped within a large wooden cabinet, surrounded by props. (See Photo below) The two narrators have very Posh Traditional southern British Accents, and the heavy make-up helps to emphasise their ghostly features.

Overall the budget is broken down into seven main compartments: Art Department, Costume, Studio space, Actors’ Travel Expenses, Catering, Equipment Hire and Transport. Funding will essentially kickstart the project into production, the money we raise, getting the gears moving. All of our crew members are already working for free, however funding would allow us to put emphasis on the Set Design, Costume and Props in particular, constructing a fleshed-out and slightly surreal world the women reside in. As the costumes and many of the props need to be fabricated, it will require artist materials alongside a large amount of time and skill. However, with the process of filmmaking there are still an enormous number of costs to cover in order to enter production. As there is a Set to be built, we will have to rent out a studio space in order to shoot. Catering and Transport will be required to facilitate both the cast and crew, and extra transport costs will be required to take props, costumes, camera and lighting equipment to the Studio. Funding would give us the opportunity to hire essential camera and lighting equipment that would help to capture the absurdist world in which the characters reside. With donations, we can achieve a high end and aesthetically pleasing piece, your donations elevating this film to a higher production standard and enabling us to tell our story.

As we are unable to pay our actors daily rates due to having a limited budget, it is essential that we must cover for their expenses and catering, in gratitude. Finally, with donations, there would be the possibility of submitting the film to Film Festivals around the world, spreading the theme of the social impact caused by oppression of creativity and individuality.

Although the key crew members are making significant financial contributions to the film, it is still impossible to achieve the budget required to create the film with their contributions alone. Here is a breakdown of our costs:

Below are a few stills from Finian's other works, which are are similar in the aesthetic that Felicity Fungus will be looking for.

By contributing to the campaign, you will be supporting young artists in the creation of something unique, helping to tell a story that delves into socially-relevant themes. In return, we have both physical and digital perks in order to thank you. These rewards contain unique props from the film, Behind The Scenes material, the script and the film itself.

Miss Felicity Fungus' Annual Maternity Tea Party is a significant story to tell in the current society we live in. We live in a world in which School shootings have become a normality, an every day event. We live in a world filled with disguised hatred for one another's culture. Why is this? This film aims to tackle the theme of oppression of individuality and creativity and how this may often lead to extremist behaviour, a matter that we as a society need to find the crux of.

If you are not able to financially contribute, there are still plenty of other ways to help in raising awareness of the project. Sharing this campaign with your communities, friends and family will help this film move into production. Any awareness you can bring to this campaign and film would be hugely appreciated.

'There is nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and bleed.' The process of filmmaking is no different. Making a film, especially on a tight budget is a huge and often painful challenge, however having worked with all of the crew members before, we have a level of trust for one another. All of us have both University and Professional film experience and we will be able to overcome our obstacles, even if at times hard to see the solution. We are fully committed in making this film, even if we don't hit our full budget. However, problems can always be solved easier when there is money to solve the problems. Without donations, it would be a much more difficult process to tell such a story.

For any information, please contact me at:

FB: Finian Clarke

IG: @the_vanilla_nautilus

Mail: finianclarke@me.com

With enthusiasm for European and Asian cinema, his extensive knowledge will be critical in the development of the creative decisions of the project, alongside the organisation.FABIO MOTA (Cinematographer) - Having recently graduated his masters in Cinematography at the Nation Film and Television School, Fabio's high attention to detail within both the Camera and Art Department is crucial for the project. His creative suggestions on set and way in which he collaborates with Finian as a Production Designer, is essential to aestheticise the film.WENZHE LI (Art Asst) - WenZhe is a multi-disciplinary artist who works in different media of performance, photography and art direction. Having collaborated in the art department alongside Finian many times before, she will be crucial in the organisation of the art department.JUSTIN KNIGHT (Asst) - When not working on his clothing brand and music, Justin is a filmmaker, interested in subversive afro-futurism, surrealism and science fiction films. With a positive way of thinking and sense of humour, Justin creates a great on-set atmosphere.DESCRIPTIONS FROM NARRATOR DIALOGUE IN SCRIPT:MISS FELICITY FUNGUS -  Miss Felicity Fungus, an aspiring author still in her jejunity, whose aptitude and intellect hast not been recognised, passes the hours pressing pen to paper, etching provocative sonnets, hiding herself within words, ideas of which come from experiences in her brief-lived but eventful wait for purgatory. To support her writing aspirations, Felicity makes her dime spending her Saturday nights spreading her legs in a room above a Chinese restaurant to greasy-haired buisnessmen, whose release of sweat from assault with a friendly weapon, smells like the pungeant chow mein they have eaten on the floor below. Her way of life has caused her to suffer from chronical urinary infection, which causes her a great deal of pain, resulting in her having regular check-ups with a man named Dr Samuel Owen Searchy. Spending her life in solitude, unless in the company of Fonula or Sybilla, Felicity passes her hours critiquing the country’s craving and parasitic obsessions to conformity.MISS FONULA DIXON-PADGETT - As a young bairn, Miss Fonula Dixon-Padgett was born with dancing blood cells and had music running through her veins. Having recognised her talents from an early age, her deceased uncle had left money on his will for Fonula to be sent to a private tutor in London away from her parents, whose pickled brains believed they had two identical twin daughters, due to their poor eyesight from spending their days guzzling pots of melted down shoe polish to feed their intoxicated minds. Whilst at her tutor, Fonula was taught the harpsichord, but had three of her fingers broken when her tutor, Mr Adley, slammed down the case on her hands. She never played again... After a change of profession, Miss Fonula yields her crowns, scrubbing underneath the large folds of skin for a senile woman named Mrs Trudy Johnson, whose appetite has certainly beaten anorexia. Fonula has experienced three miscarriages of seven pregnancies, causing her severe phobia of menopause, for which she is often teased by her present companions. She is also missing her left eyebrow, which flares up red when she is anxious or agitated.MISS SYBILLA PHLEGM - Their buckle to the belt, Miss Sybilla Phlegm, although coy on the outside, hides her abyss of complexion through the placement of pigment on canvas. Sybilla was born with trembling fingers and suffered from uncontrollable ticks and at 18 months, she had been written off as a failure. However, Sybilla spent her every day of childhood as if it were her last, applying daubs of impasto paint to paper, as it had been noticed her ticks would suddenly come to a pause when equipped with a paintbrush. Being the daughter of an architect and playwright, creativity filled the family’s oxygen-depleted blood cells, and inspiration by simply living, filled the ventricles in their every breath. Sybilla’s painting ambitions were met with her parents optimism and support, however arguments would often break when they would take her teachers’ word as gospel, when informed that Sybilla was a low-achieving student. As a whole, the family had unlocked the keyhole to happiness, however, their happiness and cackling laughter would turn into a crackle of embers, when they were caught inside their house, ablaze, Sybilla, escaping the fumes alone, bringing only a permanent growth on her lung caused by the toxic smog, which accounts to her regular coughing fits. Sybilla now lines her pockets pouring slop onto young school children’s dinner plates, stood alongside trivial half-witted women who reek of pork fat, their excess of flaky skin on their hands making its way as a garnish on the top of the dishes.NARRATORS (NOT FROM SCRIPT) - The two Narrators will be played by seven year old boys, whose head's are trapped within a large wooden cabinet, surrounded by props. (See Photo below) The two narrators have very Posh Traditional southern British Accents, and the heavy make-up helps to emphasise their ghostly features.Overall the budget is broken down into seven main compartments: Art Department, Costume, Studio space, Actors’ Travel Expenses, Catering, Equipment Hire and Transport. Funding will essentially kickstart the project into production, the money we raise, getting the gears moving. All of our crew members are already working for free, however funding would allow us to put emphasis on the Set Design, Costume and Props in particular, constructing a fleshed-out and slightly surreal world the women reside in. As the costumes and many of the props need to be fabricated, it will require artist materials alongside a large amount of time and skill. However, with the process of filmmaking there are still an enormous number of costs to cover in order to enter production. As there is a Set to be built, we will have to rent out a studio space in order to shoot. Catering and Transport will be required to facilitate both the cast and crew, and extra transport costs will be required to take props, costumes, camera and lighting equipment to the Studio. Funding would give us the opportunity to hire essential camera and lighting equipment that would help to capture the absurdist world in which the characters reside. With donations, we can achieve a high end and aesthetically pleasing piece, your donations elevating this film to a higher production standard and enabling us to tell our story.As we are unable to pay our actors daily rates due to having a limited budget, it is essential that we must cover for their expenses and catering, in gratitude. Finally, with donations, there would be the possibility of submitting the film to Film Festivals around the world, spreading the theme of the social impact caused by oppression of creativity and individuality.Although the key crew members are making significant financial contributions to the film, it is still impossible to achieve the budget required to create the film with their contributions alone. Here is a breakdown of our costs:Below are a few stills from Finian's other works, which are are similar in the aesthetic that Felicity Fungus will be looking for.By contributing to the campaign, you will be supporting young artists in the creation of something unique, helping to tell a story that delves into socially-relevant themes. In return, we have both physical and digital perks in order to thank you. These rewards contain unique props from the film, Behind The Scenes material, the script and the film itself.Miss Felicity Fungus' Annual Maternity Tea Party is a significant story to tell in the current society we live in. We live in a world in which School shootings have become a normality, an every day event. We live in a world filled with disguised hatred for one another's culture. Why is this? This film aims to tackle the theme of oppression of individuality and creativity and how this may often lead to extremist behaviour, a matter that we as a society need to find the crux of.If you are not able to financially contribute, there are still plenty of other ways to help in raising awareness of the project. Sharing this campaign with your communities, friends and family will help this film move into production. Any awareness you can bring to this campaign and film would be hugely appreciated.'There is nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and bleed.' The process of filmmaking is no different. Making a film, especially on a tight budget is a huge and often painful challenge, however having worked with all of the crew members before, we have a level of trust for one another. All of us have both University and Professional film experience and we will be able to overcome our obstacles, even if at times hard to see the solution. We are fully committed in making this film, even if we don't hit our full budget. However, problems can always be solved easier when there is money to solve the problems. Without donations, it would be a much more difficult process to tell such a story.For any information, please contact me at:FB: Finian ClarkeIG: @the_vanilla_nautilusMail: finianclarke@me.com
